title: Pass to the Cone Matching the Pass-From Colour
overview: A passing and awareness drill played in a square with one player in the middle and players on each corner. EyeQ SmartCones on the corners change colour; the central player must scan, identify the active colour, then pass to the corner whose cone matches that colour. The focus is on quick scanning and accurate passing under a simple but constant visual cue.
description:
Drill Overview
A passing and awareness drill played in a square with one player in the middle and players on each corner. EyeQ SmartCones on the corners change colour; the central player must scan, identify the active colour, then pass to the corner whose cone matches that colour. The focus is on quick scanning and accurate passing under a simple but constant visual cue.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve short passing, first touch and decision-making for the central player while keeping outside players tidy and involved.  
Scanning emphasis: The central player must scan as the ball travels back towards them, pick up the current light colour, then quickly re-scan across the four corner cones to find the matching target. If they fail to scan or guess, they are likely to pass to the wrong cone, which results in a lost point or turnover and reinforces the value of checking the cue.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 5–8 players (4 corner players and 1–2 central players)  
Area: Square of approximately 10–12m per side (adjust to age and level).  
Players: 4 players on the corners, 1–2 players working in the centre.  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones (one on each corner), 1–2 balls, flat markers if needed.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone placed at each corner of the square; each cone cycles through colours (e.g. red, blue, green, yellow) independently.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- When the ball is travelling back to the central player, one colour on the EyeQ system is active (as defined in the app).  
- The central player must pass to the corner whose EyeQ cone currently shows the same active colour.  
- If no corner cone is showing the active colour when the central player receives the ball, they must return the ball to the original passer.  
- Passing to the wrong colour or playing before clearly identifying the colour = point to defenders/coach or simple “reset” and the next player steps in.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Place a player on each corner cone and 1–2 players in the middle with a ball.  
2. A central player starts by passing to any corner player.  
3. The corner player receives and returns the ball to the central player.  
4. As the ball travels back, the EyeQ system changes the active colour; the central player must see this, then quickly scan all four cones.  
5. The central player then passes to the corner whose cone matches the active colour cue.  
6. If no cone matches, the central player passes back to the original corner and the pattern continues.  
7. After a set time or number of passes, rotate a new player into the central role.

Coaching Points
- Scan as the ball travels, not after it arrives – central player should lift their head before first touch.  
- Open body shape in the centre so they can see both the returning pass and as many corner cones as possible.  
- Crisp passing technique with the inside of the foot; weight of pass appropriate to distance.  
- Corner players check to the ball and play first-time where possible to keep tempo high.  
- Encourage communication (e.g. corners can call their colour to support the central player).

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow the central player 2–3 touches before passing; slow the cone colour changes slightly.  
- Easier: Use only two colours and two active corners to reduce complexity for younger players.  
- Harder: One-touch passing for the central player; they must already know their target before the ball arrives.  
- Harder: Add a passive defender in the middle who can intercept lazy or slow passes.  
- Harder: If the central player chooses the wrong colour, they immediately swap with that corner player as a “penalty” rotation.

title: Dribbling through Chaos
overview: Players dribble freely inside a large area while EyeQ SmartCones around the outside change colours. Each player wears a coloured bib; they must constantly scan, then dribble towards cones that match their bib colour, changing direction whenever colours change. The chaos forces young players to look up, manage space and control the ball.
description:
Drill Overview
Players dribble freely inside a large area while EyeQ SmartCones around the outside change colours. Each player wears a coloured bib; they must constantly scan, then dribble towards cones that match their bib colour, changing direction whenever colours change. The chaos forces young players to look up, manage space and control the ball.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop close dribbling control, changes of direction and basic spatial awareness in a crowded area.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must regularly lift their head to find a cone that matches their bib colour, then re-scan as colours change while they’re moving. If they lock onto one cone and ignore changes, they end up chasing the “wrong” target and must turn away, highlighting how important regular scanning is.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 8–16 players (one ball per player)  
Area: Large rectangle, roughly 25–30m x 20–25m, depending on numbers.  
Players: Every player in the middle with a ball, all active at once.  
Equipment required: 12 EyeQ SmartCones, coloured bibs (red/blue/green), 1 ball per player.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: 12 SmartCones spaced evenly around the touchlines, numbered or sequenced 1–12; cones cycle between red, blue and green.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Each player is assigned a bib colour (red, blue or green).  
- At all times, players may only “score” by dribbling to a cone that is showing their own bib colour.  
- If a cone changes to a different colour before they arrive, that cone is no longer valid and they must turn and pick a new matching cone.  
- Dribbling deliberately to a non-matching colour = no “point” and the coach can call out a quick forfeit (e.g. toe-taps) to reinforce scanning.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. All players dribble freely inside the area with a ball at their feet.  
2. The EyeQ cones around the outside change colours in a random pattern.  
3. Each player scans for a cone that currently matches their bib colour and begins to dribble towards it.  
4. If the cone colour changes mid-run, players must quickly change direction and head for a new correctly coloured cone.  
5. Once a player reaches a correct cone, they perform a turn and dribble back into space, looking up for their next target.  
6. Continue for 2–3 minutes, then rest briefly and repeat.

Coaching Points
- Encourage players to keep their head up and glance at cones while still touching the ball.  
- Emphasise small, controlled touches in tight traffic; longer touches when there is clear space.  
- Use both feet and different parts of the foot – inside, outside, laces.  
- Avoid collisions by scanning not only for cones but also for other players.  
- Praise quick changes of direction when colours switch.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Slow down the colour changes and allow players to reach cones more often before they switch.  
- Easier: Use half the cones so choices are fewer and easier to track.  
- Harder: Add a time race – how many correct cones can each player reach in 60 seconds?  
- Harder: Require a specific skill move (e.g. drag-back, inside cut) when reaching a cone.  
- Harder: Introduce 1–2 “taggers” without a ball; if tagged, a player must quickly reach a correct cone before re-joining.

title: Scan to Strike
overview: A directional small-sided game with two mini-goals at each end and an EyeQ SmartCone behind each goal. Teams keep possession while constantly scanning to see which goal in their colour is active; only that goal can be attacked. The game trains patience in build-up and fast recognition when scoring opportunities appear.
description:
Drill Overview
A directional small-sided game with two mini-goals at each end and an EyeQ SmartCone behind each goal. Teams keep possession while constantly scanning to see which goal in their colour is active; only that goal can be attacked. The game trains patients in build-up and fast recognition when a scoring opportunity appears.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve attacking decision-making, combination play and finishing in the final third when scoring opportunities open and close unpredictably.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must scan before receiving and as the ball travels to check which goal in their team colour is currently active. If no cone is lit, they must recognise that they cannot score and keep the ball; if a goal in their colour lights up, they must quickly adjust their movement and play to attack that specific target. Shooting at an inactive goal reinforces the cost of poor scanning (no goal or turnover).

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 8–14 players (4v4 to 6v6)  
Area: Approx. 35m x 25m rectangle (adjust to age and numbers).  
Players: 2 teams of 4–6 players (4v4 to 6v6, no GK).  
Equipment required: 4 mini-goals (2 at each end line), 4 EyeQ SmartCones, balls, bibs to distinguish teams.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone directly behind each mini-goal, programmed to show team colours (e.g. blue for Team A, green for Team B) and to light up randomly / in sequence.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Each team is assigned a colour (e.g. Team A = blue, Team B = green).  
- When a cone behind a goal lights up in a team’s colour, that specific goal becomes active for that team.  
- Teams may only score in a goal if their colour is currently lit behind it at the moment the ball crosses the line.  
- Goals scored at the wrong time or in a goal with no active colour = no goal; opposition restarts with possession.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Organise teams and start with a kick-off or coach pass into the middle.  
2. The team in possession keeps the ball, scanning for any goal that lights up in their colour.  
3. If a goal behind them or ahead of them lights up in their colour, they should quickly look to exploit that space with combinations or direct play.  
4. If no cone is lit in their colour, the team must maintain possession and recycle the ball rather than forcing a shot.  
5. When possession changes, the new attacking team immediately scans for a cone in their own colour and adjusts shape accordingly.  
6. Play in blocks (e.g. 3-minute games) and keep score by counting valid goals only.

Coaching Points
- Constant scanning, especially before receiving – know which goal is live before the ball comes.  
- Encourage quick, positive play when a goal opens: support runs, third-man runs, and early shots.  
- Reinforce patient possession when no goal is available; discourage hopeful long shots.  
- Defenders should adjust position to protect likely active goals, shifting quickly when lights change.  
- Emphasise communication: players shout when “our” goal lights up.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow a goal to stay active for a few extra seconds after the light goes off.  
- Easier: Let teams score in any goal once their colour has been lit, to reduce cognitive load.  
- Harder: Require at least two passes after the goal becomes active before a shot is allowed.  
- Harder: Limit touches (e.g. 2-touch) to encourage faster decision-making.  
- Harder: Add a neutral playmaker who always plays with the team in possession, increasing tempo and complexity.

title: Dribbling with a Changing Target
overview: Players dribble inside a grid filled with several small EyeQ "goals" made from pairs of SmartCones. At any time, one or more of these goals light up and become live targets. Players must dribble through a lit goal to "score", then immediately look up to find the next live goal as targets change.
description:
Drill Overview
Players dribble inside a grid filled with several small EyeQ “goals” made from pairs of SmartCones. At any time, one or more of these goals light up and become live targets. Players must dribble through a lit goal to “score”, then immediately look up to find the next live goal as targets change.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve dribbling, changes of direction and quick reactions to new attacking targets.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must scan repeatedly to locate which EyeQ goals are currently lit, change direction when goals switch off, and avoid committing to an “old” target. When a goal’s lights go off, they must stop attacking that goal and find the next lit pair, underlining the importance of constant visual checking.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 8–12 players (all dribblers)  
Area: 30m x 25m grid (adjust to numbers and age).  
Players: 8–12 dribblers, each with their own ball.  
Equipment required: 4 cones to mark the outer area; 6 small goals made from pairs of EyeQ SmartCones; 1 ball per player.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Six pairs of SmartCones placed randomly inside the grid to form 1m-wide mini-goals. EyeQ system lights one or more pairs at a time.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Only EyeQ goals that are currently lit count as valid scoring targets.  
- When a pair of cones is lit, dribbling through that gate earns a point.  
- When a lit goal turns off, it instantly becomes “dead” – players must stop attacking it and find a new lit goal.  
- Attempting to score through an unlit goal does not count; players must immediately turn away and re-scan.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. All players start inside the grid with a ball, dribbling freely.  
2. One or more EyeQ goals light up; players scan and dribble to attack any lit goal.  
3. To score, players must dribble cleanly through the lit gate under control.  
4. As soon as they score, they turn back into the grid, lift their head and search for the next lit goal.  
5. When a goal switches off, players must immediately stop heading for it and find a new live target.  
6. Run for 60–90 seconds, then rest briefly and repeat with a new challenge (e.g. weaker foot only).

Coaching Points
- Head up regularly – players should spot changes early, not at the last second.  
- Close control in traffic; bigger touches when moving into space towards a gate.  
- Quick decision to abandon a dead target and re-attack a new one.  
- Encourage creativity in turns and changes of direction.  
- Praise players who react first when a new goal lights.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Reduce the number of goals and slow down the change rate.  
- Easier: Allow goals to stay lit for longer once activated.  
- Harder: Make red-lit goals worth double points to encourage prioritisation.  
- Harder: Introduce a time limit – how many valid goals can each player hit in 60 seconds?  
- Harder: Add 1–2 “defenders” who move without a ball and try to block access to goals.

title: Warm-Up Ball Control & Awareness
overview: A two-part warm-up combining individual ball mastery and a partner-based awareness game. EyeQ SmartCones show different colours that tell dribblers which part of the foot to use; when the lights go dark, players must quickly pass and switch roles with their partner. It's a fun way to activate scanning, technique and communication at the start of a session.
description:
Drill Overview
A two-part warm-up combining individual ball mastery and a partner-based awareness game. EyeQ SmartCones show different colours that tell dribblers which part of the foot to use; when the lights go dark, players must quickly pass and switch roles with their partner. It’s a fun way to activate scanning, technique and communication at the start of a session.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Activate players physically while improving ball control, use of different foot surfaces and basic awareness of team-mates in traffic.  
Scanning emphasis: In Part 1, players scan for the current colour instruction (laces, inside, outside) while still managing the ball; in Part 2, dribblers must also scan to locate their partner and time the exchange when the cones go dark. Failing to scan leads to using the wrong surface or missing the moment to pass.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 10–20 players  
Area: 20m x 20m grid (adjust for numbers).  
Players: Any number; for Part 2 they work in pairs (one dribbler, one runner).  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones to mark the grid, 1 ball between two players (or 1 each for Part 1).  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Four SmartCones form the corners of the grid, cycling through colours (e.g. green, blue, yellow) and fully turning off at intervals.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Green = laces dribbling only.  
- Blue = inside of the right foot only.  
- Yellow = outside of the left foot only.  
- All cones dark = immediately stop the ball with the sole and, in Part 2, pass to your partner and swap roles.  
- Ignoring the current colour (wrong surface or failing to pass when dark) = simple reminder or small forfeit from coach to reinforce attention.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
**Part 1 – Individual Ball Control**
1. Every player has a ball and dribbles freely inside the grid.  
2. EyeQ cones show a colour; players must dribble using only the corresponding foot surface.  
3. When cones change colour, players adjust their touches to match the new instruction.  
4. When cones go dark, players stop their ball quickly with the sole, then wait for the next colour.

**Part 2 – Dribble & Exchange**
5. Players pair up; one becomes dribbler (with ball), the other runner (without ball).  
6. Dribbler continues to follow the colour-based foot-surface instructions while dribbling in the grid.  
7. Runner moves freely, finding space and staying available for a pass.  
8. When cones go dark, the dribbler must quickly locate their partner, pass the ball and switch roles – runner becomes dribbler, dribbler becomes runner.  
9. Play continuously for 4–6 minutes with frequent colour and dark phases.

Coaching Points
- Keep the head up regularly while dribbling; don’t stare at the ball.  
- Many small touches for control, especially in tight areas.  
- Clear difference between laces / inside / outside touches.  
- Sharp stop with the sole when cones go dark; react quickly to switch.  
- In Part 2, runners must communicate and show in good space to receive passes.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Use only two colours (e.g. laces and inside) for younger players.  
- Easier: Allow a few seconds delay after cones go dark before players must exchange.  
- Harder: Make all exchanges “weaker foot only” passes.  
- Harder: Add a simple skill action (e.g. step-over) that the new dribbler must perform before dribbling.  
- Harder: Introduce 1–2 passive defenders who move in the grid to add traffic and force better scanning.

title: Follow the Ball
overview: A passing circle played around a square with players at each corner and one ball (or two) circulating. EyeQ SmartCones in the corners change colour; receivers must scan, call out the current colour and take a purposeful first touch before passing on and following their pass. The drill sharpens scanning, communication and simple passing technique.
description:
Drill Overview
A passing circle played around a square with players at each corner and one ball (or two) circulating. EyeQ SmartCones in the corners change colour; receivers must scan, call out the current colour and take a purposeful first touch before passing on and following their pass. The drill sharpens scanning, communication and simple passing technique.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve basic passing, first touch and body orientation while encouraging players to check their surroundings before receiving.  
Scanning emphasis: As the ball travels towards them, receivers must quickly glance at their corner cone, register the colour and call it out before their first touch. Because colours can change at any moment, players are pushed to scan repeatedly, not just once; failing to scan leads to late or incorrect calls and poor preparation.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 8–12 players  
Area: 20m x 20m square (adjust size to age and passing ability).  
Players: 2–3 players per corner (8–12 total).  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones (one at each corner), 1–2 balls.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone on or just behind each corner cone, changing colours randomly at a steady tempo.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- The current colour showing at a player’s corner must be called out loudly (“Red!”, “Blue!” etc.) before they take their first touch.  
- The colour itself does not initially change the action – the key is identifying and verbalising it in time.  
- Optional advanced mapping (progression):  
  - Red = pass with left foot, Blue = pass with right foot, Green = two-touch max.  
- Failure to call the colour before first touch or using the wrong action in the progression = loss of point for that group or quick reset.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Place 2–3 players at each corner with one ball starting at a designated corner.  
2. Player at Cone 1 passes to the first player at Cone 2.  
3. As the ball travels, the receiver at Cone 2 glances at their SmartCone, sees the colour and calls it out loudly before control.  
4. The receiver takes a positive first touch towards the next corner, then passes to Cone 3.  
5. After passing, they follow their pass to join the end of the line at the next corner.  
6. The pattern continues around the square in a continuous flow: Receive → Call colour → Control → Pass → Follow.  
7. Add a second ball from the opposite corner once the rhythm is good.

Coaching Points
- “Head on a swivel” – glance at the cone as the ball travels, not once it has arrived.  
- Side-on body position to see both the ball and the cone with minimal head movement.  
- First touch should move into space and set up the next pass.  
- Clear, early communication of the colour to show that scanning has happened.  
- Weight and accuracy of pass to maintain tempo.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow extra touches and slow the colour change rate.  
- Easier: Remove any colour-action mapping and focus only on scanning and calling.  
- Harder: Add colour-coded actions (e.g. red = left foot pass, blue = right foot, green = one-touch).  
- Harder: Start a second ball and challenge players to avoid collisions or confusion.  
- Harder: Add a passive defender in the middle who can intercept poorly weighted passes.

title: Neutral Zone Pass - Dual Grid Reactive Switch
overview: Two teams play separate possession games in two side-by-side grids separated by a narrow neutral channel. EyeQ SmartCones around each grid give colour cues that tell the ball carrier whether to switch play by a long pass or by dribbling through the neutral channel, or to keep the ball in their current grid. Both teams must scan their cones and the opposite grid to act correctly and in sync with the cue.
description:
Drill Overview
Two teams play separate possession games in two side-by-side grids separated by a narrow neutral channel. EyeQ SmartCones around each grid give colour cues that tell the ball carrier whether to switch play by a long pass or by dribbling through the neutral channel, or to keep the ball in their current grid. Both teams must scan their cones and the opposite grid to act correctly and in sync with the cue.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop the ability to switch play intelligently, either by a long pass or by carrying the ball, while maintaining quality possession.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must scan not only within their own grid for passing options but also the EyeQ cones and the far grid. When the cue changes, the ball carrier must instantly decide whether to play long, dribble across or keep the ball. Ignoring the cue or hesitating too long leads to turnovers and lost switching opportunities.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 10 players (5v5 in two grids)  
Area: 35m x 20m, divided into Grid A (15m x 20m), a 5m neutral channel, and Grid B (15m x 20m).  
Players: 2 teams of 5 (one team in each grid).  
Equipment required: 6 EyeQ SmartCones (3 around each grid), 2 balls, bibs, flat markers for zones.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Three SmartCones spaced around Grid A and three around Grid B; all cones in a grid show the same colour at any moment.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Blue = Switch by long pass: the ball carrier must play a long pass to an open team-mate in the opposite grid.  
- Red = Switch by dribble: the ball carrier must dribble through the neutral channel into the opposite grid then pass.  
- Yellow = Stay: team continues to keep possession within their current grid.  
- Failing to act on blue or red within a reasonable time, or switching incorrectly, results in a turnover to the opposition.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Team A starts with a ball in Grid A; Team B starts with a ball in Grid B.  
2. Both teams keep possession in their own grid, using short passes and movement.  
3. EyeQ cones in each grid display a colour; all three in a grid always match.  
4. When cones in a grid turn blue, the ball carrier must quickly scan and play a long pass to a team-mate in the opposite grid; then players adjust their positions accordingly.  
5. When cones turn red, the ball carrier must dribble across the neutral channel into the opposite grid before passing.  
6. When cones are yellow, teams continue to possess the ball inside their own grid.  
7. If a team fails to respond correctly to the cue or loses the ball, the opposition takes over possession and plays under the same rules.  
8. Rotate players between grids and roles regularly.

Coaching Points
- Pre-scan before receiving: players should know where space and team-mates are in the opposite grid.  
- Quality of long passes – driven, accurate, and timed to match the movement of receivers.  
- Positive, decisive dribbling through the neutral channel when red shows.  
- Off-the-ball players adjust width and depth in anticipation of possible switches.  
- Quick reaction to cues – avoid “freezing” when colours change.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow players to complete a pass or two in the new grid before enforcing the next cue.  
- Easier: Use only two colours (blue = pass switch, yellow = stay) until players are comfortable.  
- Harder: On blue, the switch must be played first-time where possible.  
- Harder: Limit touches (e.g. 2-touch) inside the grids.  
- Harder: Add one floating defender who can move between grids to create unpredictability.

title: Hot Zone Pass - EyeQ Hot Zone Possession Game
overview: A directional small-sided game played towards an endzone. Twelve EyeQ SmartCones along the back edge of the endzone define a shifting "hot zone" where only that strip is valid for scoring. Attackers must scan across the line of cones to find the current hot zone, time their pass into it, and have a team-mate run on to control the ball there.
description:
Drill Overview
A directional small-sided game played towards an endzone. Twelve EyeQ SmartCones along the back edge of the endzone define a shifting “hot zone” where only that strip is valid for scoring. Attackers must scan across the line of cones to find the current hot zone, time their pass into it, and have a team-mate run on to control the ball there.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Train players to recognise and exploit dangerous spaces in behind the defence with well-timed runs and passes.  
Scanning emphasis: Ball-carriers must scan across the entire back line of cones to identify which section is currently lit and, therefore, live. Runners must also scan regularly to anticipate where to run. If attackers fail to scan or rush the pass into a dead area, the chance is wasted and the ball turns over or no point is scored.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 10–14 players (5v5 or 6v6)  
Area: Half pitch with an added 10–15m endzone behind the defending line.  
Players: 2 teams of 5 or 6 (5v5 or 6v6).  
Equipment required: 12 EyeQ SmartCones, balls, bibs, markers for endzone.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: 12 SmartCones spread evenly along or just behind the back edge of the endzone; at any time, four cones form the current hot zone by lighting up (e.g. green).

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Four cones lit in the same colour define the current hot zone (live scoring strip).  
- To score, the attacking team must play a pass into the endzone so that a team-mate runs onto the ball and controls it inside the space in front of the lit cones.  
- Attackers may not stand waiting inside the endzone; runs must be timed from outside.  
- Passes or receptions outside the hot zone or with players already stationed in the endzone do not score; ball remains in play or is turned over by coach decision.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Set up the half pitch with a clearly marked endzone and the line of SmartCones.  
2. One team begins in possession and attempts to build up play towards the endzone.  
3. Defenders press to win the ball but must respect the space of the endzone (no camping inside if you wish to keep it clear).  
4. As play develops, four cones along the back line are lit, marking the current hot zone.  
5. The attacking team must scan, identify the hot zone and play a well-timed pass into that strip for a team-mate to run onto and control.  
6. Successful controlled reception inside the hot zone = 1 point (or “goal”).  
7. When defenders win the ball, they immediately transition to attack the opposite way under the same rules.  
8. Play in time blocks and keep score.

Coaching Points
- Ball-carrier scans across the back line before deciding when and where to play the through pass.  
- Runners time their movement – “wait, then break” – so they arrive in the hot zone just as the ball does.  
- Encourage disguise and variety in passes (driven, clipped, slide passes).  
- On loss of possession, immediate reaction to defend and prevent the opponents’ hot zone entry.  
- Communication about where the hot zone is (“Right side!”, “Middle!”) to support team-mates.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow attackers to score by simply dribbling into the hot zone under control.  
- Easier: Widen the endzone or keep the hot zone larger for more frequent success.  
- Harder: Reduce touches for the attacking team in build-up (e.g. 2-touch).  
- Harder: Split the endzone into three narrower vertical channels and award extra points for hitting wide or far-side zones.  
- Harder: Add an offside line to encourage timing of runs and discourage early movement.

title: Progressive Zone Build and Score
overview: Three attackers work the ball up a narrow pitch divided into four zones, with one or two defenders free to defend across all zones. Each of the first three zones has EyeQ SmartCones; attackers may only step into the next zone when that zone's cones show the correct cue. The defenders can score on any regain, creating constant jeopardy.
description:
Drill Overview
Three attackers work the ball up a narrow pitch divided into four zones, with one or two defenders free to defend across all zones. Each of the first three zones has EyeQ SmartCones; attackers may only step into the next zone when that zone’s cones show the correct cue. The defenders can score on any regain, creating constant jeopardy.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop patient yet purposeful build-up play, controlled progression through the thirds and intelligent defensive transitions.  
Scanning emphasis: Attackers must regularly scan the cones in the *next* zone rather than just focusing on their current space. When the correct cue appears, they must quickly transition forward as a unit. If they rush without checking, they risk advancing illegally and being reset; if they stare only at defenders, they miss safe windows to progress.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 4–5 players (3 attackers + 1–2 defenders)  
Area: Narrow channel about 40m long by 12–15m wide, divided into four equal 10m zones.  
Players: 3 attackers vs 1 defender (or 3v2 for more pressure).  
Equipment required: 12 EyeQ SmartCones (3 at the front of each of Zones 1–3), markers for zone lines, 1–2 balls, a goal in Zone 4.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Three SmartCones at the front edge of each of Zones 1, 2 and 3, visible to attackers in the preceding zone.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- A specified colour (e.g. green) appearing on all three cones in the *next* zone = permission to advance into that zone while in possession.  
- Any other colour or dark cones in the next zone = attackers must stay in their current zone, keeping the ball under pressure.  
- Advancing into a zone when the correct cue is not showing results in a reset back to the previous zone or turnover by coach decision.  
- In Zone 4 (final zone), no cue is needed – attackers may finish freely once they arrive legally.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Attackers start in Zone 1 with the ball, defender(s) free to move in any zone.  
2. Attackers keep possession in Zone 1 and scan the SmartCones at the front of Zone 2.  
3. When Zone 2’s cones show the correct colour cue, attackers combine to carry or pass the ball into Zone 2 as a group.  
4. The same pattern repeats from Zone 2 to Zone 3 – hold, scan, then progress when allowed.  
5. Once attackers legally reach Zone 4, they are free to combine and shoot at goal without further cues.  
6. If defenders win the ball at any time, they can immediately shoot from wherever they are or dribble to a better shooting position.  
7. After a goal (by either side) or a reset, rotate roles so everyone experiences attacking and defending.

Coaching Points
- Attackers must scan forward cones regularly, not just defenders and team-mates.  
- Possession with purpose – don’t force forward play when the cue is not showing.  
- Move as a unit into the next zone to support the ball and avoid isolation.  
- Defenders look to anticipate likely progression moments and press aggressively then.  
- Positive, composed finishing in Zone 4.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow attackers to advance if at least two of the three cones in the next zone show the correct colour.  
- Easier: Remove one defender so attackers can experience success with the progression pattern.  
- Harder: Add a second defender (3v2) for extra pressure.  
- Harder: Limit touches for attackers in each zone (e.g. maximum 3 passes before cue appears).  
- Harder: Require a minimum of one pass in the new zone before moving on again, to discourage one-player runs.

title: EyeQ Call Possession Game
overview: Two teams play a tight possession game inside a square. An EyeQ SmartCone on each side of the grid lights up in different colours; when a cone lights, the team in possession must respond with a specific action, such as switching play to the opposite side or completing a series of one-touch passes. The game rewards teams that scan early and react quickly to colour cues while keeping the ball.
description:
Drill Overview
Two teams play a tight possession game inside a square. An EyeQ SmartCone on each side of the grid lights up in different colours; when a cone lights, the team in possession must respond with a specific action, such as switching play to the opposite side or completing a series of one-touch passes. The game rewards teams that scan early and react quickly to colour cues while keeping the ball.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve possession play, quick reactions to external cues and team coordination under pressure.  
Scanning emphasis: All players, not just the ball carrier, must keep an eye on the four side cones. When a colour appears, they must link that colour to the assigned task and adjust their play accordingly. If they fail to notice or react too slowly, they lose possession or points, reinforcing the need for constant head movement and shared awareness.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 10–14 players (5v5 or 6v6)  
Area: 30m x 30m grid (adjust to numbers and ability).  
Players: 2 teams (5v5 or 6v6).  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones (one on the midpoint of each side), 1 ball, bibs.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone on each side line at the midpoint; cones light up individually at random intervals in red or blue.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Red cone lights on one side: the team in possession must switch the ball to the opposite side of the grid within a maximum of three passes.  
- Blue cone lights: the team in possession must complete three consecutive one-touch passes anywhere in the grid.  
- Failing to complete the required action in time, or losing the ball before doing so, results in immediate turnover to the opposing team from the spot.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Organise teams and start play with a simple pass-in or kick-off.  
2. Teams compete to keep possession in the grid using normal football rules.  
3. At random intervals, one of the four side cones lights up in red or blue.  
4. As soon as the cue appears, the team in possession must recognise the colour and execute the rule:  
   - Red: move the ball to the opposite side of the grid within three passes.  
   - Blue: complete three one-touch passes in a row.  
5. If they succeed, play continues as normal until the next cue.  
6. If they fail or lose the ball, possession switches to the other team, who then responds to the next cue that appears.  
7. Play in short, intense blocks (e.g. 3–4 minutes) and keep score by number of successful cue responses or by goals if you add end goals.

Coaching Points
- Encourage players to scan the whole grid, including the side cones, even when off the ball.  
- Stress quick recognition and a clear team decision after each cue – one simple plan: “Red = open up and switch; Blue = tighten passes.”  
- Support angles and body shape should make switching and one-touch play possible.  
- Emphasise communication – players can shout “Red!” or “Blue!” to alert team-mates.  
- Encourage calm possession between cues, not constant rushing.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow more passes to complete each task (e.g. five passes to switch after red).  
- Easier: Use only one colour and one rule until players are comfortable.  
- Harder: Add small goals on two sides; teams can score after successfully completing a cue.  
- Harder: Introduce a third colour with a new rule (e.g. yellow = everyone must touch the ball before losing possession).  
- Harder: Reduce touch limit (e.g. 2-touch max) to push scanning and pre-orientation.

title: EyeQ Chaos Possession Game - Neutral Trigger
overview: A possession rondo with two teams and an EyeQ SmartCone in the centre. When the central cone lights up in a "neutral" colour, the ball must immediately be passed through that cone for a neutral player to receive and switch play. When the cone goes dark, teams play normal possession. The frequent light changes demand constant scanning and quick decision-making from all players.
description:
Drill Overview
Three teams share one possession game inside a single grid. Two teams combine to keep the ball while the third team defends. At random moments a neutral EyeQ cone lights up and instantly places a time/ pass constraint on the team currently on the ball, forcing them to react quickly under pressure.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop scanning, rapid recognition of triggers and coordinated team reactions in tight possession and transition moments.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must continually scan not only for team-mates and defenders but also the neutral EyeQ cone. As soon as it lights, the team in possession must recognise the cue and complete the required number of passes in the time window. If they fail to scan or delay, they lose the ball and roles change, making scanning a constant requirement.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 12–18 players (3 teams of 4–6)  
Area: 30m x 30m grid (adjust to numbers).  
Players: 3 teams of 4–6 players, each in a different bib colour (e.g. red, blue, yellow).  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones, 1 ball (plus spares), cones to mark area, bibs.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Four SmartCones spaced evenly along the sidelines of the grid, all linked to show the same neutral colour cue.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Yellow light (or chosen cue colour) = chaos trigger for the team currently in possession of the ball.  
- When the trigger appears, the team with the ball must complete 3 passes within 6 seconds.  
- During this period, their partner possession team may not receive the ball but should move to create space and support options.  
- Failure to complete 3 passes in time, or losing possession during the cue window, results in an immediate turnover and the team that lost the ball becomes the new defenders.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Organise three teams and place all players inside the grid.  
2. Two teams start as possession teams and combine to keep the ball; the third team defends.  
3. Play begins with a pass from the coach or a free ball in the grid.  
4. Teams in possession move the ball, using each other freely while defenders try to win it back.  
5. At random intervals, an EyeQ cone lights up in the neutral cue colour. The team currently on the ball must complete 3 passes within 6 seconds.  
6. If they succeed, play continues and cones go back to neutral/off until the next trigger.  
7. If they fail or lose the ball, the team that lost possession becomes defenders, and the defending team that won the ball joins the other possession team.  
8. Rotate roles regularly so all teams experience attacking and defending.

Coaching Points
- Possession teams: scan regularly – see the ball, team-mates, opponents and the EyeQ cone.  
- React quickly to the cue: one- and two-touch passes, sharp movement to create simple options.  
- Non-receiving possession team supports with angles and depth without demanding the ball during the 3-pass window.  
- Defenders press most aggressively when the cue appears, knowing the attackers are under extra pressure.  
- Encourage constant communication (“Yellow! Three passes!”) to share awareness.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Increase the time window (e.g. 8–10 seconds) or reduce the required passes to 2.  
- Easier: Allow the second possession team to receive during the cue period.  
- Harder: Increase the pass requirement to 4–5 passes in 6 seconds.  
- Harder: Add a touch limit (e.g. 2-touch) for the team under the cue.  
- Harder: Use two different cue colours with slightly different tasks (e.g. yellow = 3 passes, red = 2 one-touch passes).

title: Keep Possession with Shielding Cue
overview: Players maintain possession in a tight grid while EyeQ SmartCones around the perimeter show different colours. When a cone shows red, players must shield the ball with their body rather than passing immediately; when the cone is blue or green, they can pass freely. The exercise teaches players to recognise when to hold possession under pressure and when to release the ball.
description:
Drill Overview
A simple possession game in a tight area where EyeQ SmartCones around the pitch occasionally light up. Whenever a cone lights, the current ball-carrier must immediately shield the ball until the light goes off, then resume normal play. This creates repeated moments of controlled shielding under live pressure.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop ball retention under pressure, body use for shielding and composure when pressed.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must constantly scan the perimeter cones while playing. When a cone lights, the ball-carrier must quickly recognise the cue and shift from passing mode to shielding mode. If they miss the cue and keep playing as normal, the coach can call a turnover, making visual awareness central to success.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 8–12 players (4v4 or 5v5)  
Area: 20m x 20m grid (tight enough to create pressure).  
Players: 2 teams of 4–6 players (e.g. 4v4 or 5v5).  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones around perimeter, 1 ball (plus spares), bibs, cones for grid.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Four SmartCones at midpoints of each side line.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Any cone lighting in the chosen cue colour = shielding trigger for the current ball-carrier.  
- While the cone is lit, the ball-carrier must protect the ball and not pass or shoot.  
- Once the light goes off, they must pass to a team-mate to resume normal play.  
- Ignoring the cue (continuing to pass while the cone is lit) or losing the ball during the shielding phase can result in an automatic turnover.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Set up the grid and split players into two equal teams.  
2. One team starts in possession and attempts to keep the ball using short passes and movement.  
3. Defenders press realistically, trying to win possession.  
4. At random moments, one of the EyeQ cones around the perimeter lights up.  
5. As soon as it lights, the player in possession must immediately shift to shielding: use their body to protect the ball from defenders until the light turns off.  
6. Once the light goes off, that player must make a pass to a team-mate and normal possession resumes.  
7. If defenders win the ball, they become the team in possession and operate under the same rules when the next cue appears.  
8. Play in short rounds (2–3 minutes), then reset or swap starting team.

Coaching Points
- Ball-carrier: strong body position between defender and ball, use of arms for balance, low centre of gravity.  
- Head up even while shielding – feel the pressure but still scan for next pass option.  
- Team-mates must move to support and offer passing lanes immediately once the light goes off.  
- Defenders: time their tackle attempts, especially just as the light goes out and the ball-carrier prepares to pass.  
- Emphasise composure: no panic when cones light; protect, then play.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow the ball-carrier a safe zone (e.g. 1m bubble) where defenders can pressure but not tackle while the light is on.  
- Easier: Extend the shielding time so players have longer to organise their body position.  
- Harder: Require the ball-carrier to perform a specific turn or escape move immediately after the light goes off before passing.  
- Harder: Reduce the grid size or add an extra defender to increase pressure.  
- Harder: Award bonus points for successful shielding sequences that end in a forward pass.

title: 2v2 Multi-Cue Reaction Game
overview: Two 2v2 games run simultaneously in adjacent grids, each with their own EyeQ SmartCones. The cones give real-time instructions that affect gameplay, such as one-touch only, weaker foot only, or switching the direction of attack. Players must continuously monitor the cones in their grid and adapt their play instantly when colours change.
description:
Drill Overview
A tight 2v2 possession game inside a small square with EyeQ SmartCones on each corner. The cones change colour and dictate different actions for the ball-carrier, such as switching play, shielding or playing one-touch. Players must process the cue and execute the correct action instantly under live defensive pressure.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve 2v2 possession, shielding, quick combinations and decision-making under pressure.  
Scanning emphasis: Both attackers and defenders must constantly scan the corner cones while playing. The ball-carrier in particular must read the cue as the ball is arriving and adjust whether to switch, shield or play one-touch. Failing to scan leads to wrong actions and turnovers, reinforcing the need to link visual information to tactical choices.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 4 players per grid (2v2)  
Area: 15m x 15m square.  
Players: 2 attackers vs 2 defenders inside the square.  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones (one on each corner), 1 ball, bibs.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone at each corner of the square, all connected to cycle between green, yellow and blue.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Green = Switch play: the attacking pair must move the ball quickly to the opposite side of the square.  
- Yellow = Shield: the ball-carrier must protect the ball for a few seconds before passing.  
- Blue = One-touch: the next pass from the ball-carrier must be one-touch if possible.  
- Ignoring the cue or failing to complete the required action in a reasonable time results in a turnover to the opposition or a lost point.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Set up the square with 2 attackers and 2 defenders inside.  
2. Coach serves the ball to the attacking pair to start play.  
3. Attackers aim to keep possession, moving and combining to beat pressure.  
4. Throughout play, EyeQ cones change colour at random intervals.  
5. When a colour appears, the ball-carrier must immediately act according to that cue:
   - Green: move the ball across to the opposite side of the square (e.g. via a pass and support run).  
   - Yellow: use body to shield and hold the ball for a brief count before passing.  
   - Blue: play the next pass one-touch if possible.  
6. Defenders try to win the ball and, on winning it, become the attacking pair, now working under the same cues.  
7. After 60–90 seconds, rotate new players into the grid.

Coaching Points
- Attackers: scan cones before and during receiving – don’t wait until after control.  
- Body shape side-on to see both ball and cones in one glance.  
- Positive, strong shielding when yellow shows: use body, hips and arms legally.  
- Quick passing combinations and support angles for green and blue cues.  
- Defenders: read cues too; time pressing based on likely attacker actions.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Use only one or two colours (e.g. green and blue) at first.  
- Easier: Enlarge the grid slightly to provide more space.  
- Harder: Add a time or pass limit for attackers to complete each cue action.  
- Harder: Reduce grid size for more pressure.  
- Harder: Add a neutral support player on the outside who can be used only under certain colours (e.g. green).

title: Pass Through Centre - EyeQ Central Rondo
overview: A central rondo with attackers keeping possession around the outside while defenders work in the middle. EyeQ SmartCones positioned around the perimeter and in the centre create dynamic passing lanes. When certain cones light up, attackers must use specific combinations or routes through the middle. The drill improves decision-making, passing precision and movement off the ball.
description:
Drill Overview
Two teams play possession around a central square, supported by one or two neutrals. EyeQ SmartCones on the outside edges provide colour cues that change the passing task: sometimes the ball must go through the central square, sometimes it must be switched wide, and sometimes the ball-carrier must shield. The game connects scanning with different build-up behaviours.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve build-up play, including central penetration, wide switches and shielding under pressure.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must keep an eye on the side cones while circulating the ball. A green cue means they must find a pass through the central square; blue means switching play; yellow creates a short shielding task. If players fail to scan and miss the cue, they miss scoring chances or concede possession via coach decision.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 10–12 players (4v4 or 5v5 plus neutrals)  
Area: 20m x 20m outer square with a 5m x 5m central square marked inside.  
Players: 2 teams of 4–5 players (4v4 or 5v5) plus 1–2 neutrals who play with the team in possession.  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones, cones or markers for outer and central squares, 1 ball, bibs.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone on each side of the outer square, all visible from inside.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Green = Central pass: the team in possession must complete a pass that goes through or into the central square to a team-mate.  
- Blue = Switch: the ball must be switched to the opposite side of the outer square (e.g. from left to right).  
- Yellow = Shield: the current ball-carrier must shield the ball for a moment (e.g. 2–3 seconds) before releasing a pass.  
- If no cone is lit, normal possession rules apply with no special task.  
- Failing to fulfil the cue within a set number of passes or seconds results in a turnover or loss of a point.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Mark the outer square and central square, and place teams and neutrals as described.  
2. One team starts with the ball, supported by neutrals; the other team defends.  
3. The attacking team keeps possession, looking to exploit neutrals and create angles.  
4. EyeQ cones on the sides light up in different colours at random intervals.  
5. When a colour appears, the team in possession must quickly respond:
   - Green: play through or into the central square to a team-mate or neutral.  
   - Blue: move the ball across to the opposite side of the grid.  
   - Yellow: current ball-carrier shields briefly before passing.  
6. Once the task is completed, play returns to normal possession until the next cue.  
7. If the defending team wins the ball, roles reverse and they now follow the cues.  
8. Play for several timed rounds, rotating neutrals and team roles.

Coaching Points
- Attackers: scan side cones regularly, not just team-mates and defenders.  
- Use neutrals smartly to help access the central square or to switch play quickly.  
- Encourage body position that allows quick turns and shielding when yellow appears.  
- Defenders: adjust pressure based on cue – press aggressively when an action is required.  
- Emphasise quick decision-making once a colour appears – avoid hesitation.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Only use two colours at first (e.g. green = central pass, blue = switch).  
- Easier: Allow extra time or passes to complete each task.  
- Harder: Restrict touches (e.g. 2-touch) to increase tempo and cognitive load.  
- Harder: Add a scoring system (e.g. 1 point for successful green or blue tasks, bonus for completing both in a sequence).  
- Harder: Force a directional element by adding goals or end zones that can only be attacked after completing specific cues.

title: Red to Blue to Yellow - Colour Chain Game
overview: A possession game where players must complete a specific passing sequence dictated by EyeQ SmartCone colours. For example, a pass to a red cone must be followed by a pass to a blue cone, then to a yellow cone before resetting. Sequences can be linear or branching. The exercise trains pattern recognition, communication and rapid visual processing under possession pressure.
description:
Drill Overview
Three colour-coded teams share one ball inside a grid. Players initially pass within their own colour group, but EyeQ SmartCones change the “passing chain”: red must pass to blue, blue to yellow, yellow to red, and sometimes any colour is allowed. This forces continuous scanning of cones and bib colours and quick adaptation of passing targets.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop awareness of team-mates, opponent groups and changing passing rules in a crowded possession game.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must scan both the EyeQ cones and the bib colours of other groups. When a new colour lights, the rule for who you can pass to changes instantly. If players fail to scan and pass to an illegal colour, they lose possession and quickly understand the need to link visual cues with decisions.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 9–15 players (3 colour groups of 3–5)  
Area: 25m x 20m grid (adapt to numbers).  
Players: 3 groups of equal size, each in a different bib colour (red, blue, yellow).  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones, 1 ball, bibs, cones for boundaries.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Four SmartCones around the grid; all show the same colour at any one time (red, blue, yellow, or green).

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Red light: red players may only pass to blue players; blue and yellow must still obey the current rule shown.  
- Blue light: blue players may only pass to yellow players.  
- Yellow light: yellow players may only pass to red players.  
- Green light (all cones): free passing – any colour may pass to any group.  
- Passing to the wrong colour when a restricted colour is showing = turnover to the team that should have received legally, or to coach’s choice.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. All players move freely in the grid; start with simple same-colour passing to warm up.  
2. Introduce the EyeQ cones and explain the colour chain rules.  
3. Begin with a ball in play: the first team in possession passes according to the current rule (e.g. red passes must go to blue if red is showing).  
4. Players move continuously to create passing options that match the rule.  
5. When the EyeQ colour changes, passing restrictions change immediately – the ball-carrier must adjust their next pass to the new cue.  
6. If a player passes illegally (to a wrong group for the current colour), that pass results in a turnover.  
7. Play in short, intense rounds, then reset and swap start team or add a second ball.

Coaching Points
- Players should scan both the cones and the bib colours of potential targets before receiving.  
- Emphasise good movement off the ball to provide passing options that fit the current rule.  
- Encourage early communication: players shout when their colour becomes “live”.  
- Keep technical quality high – accurate passes and good first touch in tight spaces.  
- Encourage players to plan ahead: “If the light changes, who will be my next option?”

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Start with only two colours active (e.g. red and blue chain) plus green for free play.  
- Easier: Give a short grace period when the colour changes before enforcing the new rule strictly.  
- Harder: Add 1–2 defenders who can intercept any pass; if they win the ball, they join the group that “should” have received.  
- Harder: Add a touch limit to increase tempo and cognitive load.  
- Harder: Award points for sequences of correct colour-chain passes without turnovers.

title: Four Corners EyeQ Reaction Game
overview: Four small goals are set in the corners of a playing area, each with an EyeQ SmartCone. Two teams compete; at any moment, one or more goals light up and only those goals are live for scoring. Teams must scan constantly, recognise when their target goal is active and attack it before the light changes. The drill sharpens transition speed and situational awareness in a fun, competitive format.
description:
Drill Overview
Two teams play a directional game inside a rectangle with four small goals, one in each corner. EyeQ SmartCones behind the goals determine which goal is currently live, and occasionally introduce a pass-count requirement before finishing. Players must scan which corner is lit and adjust their attacks on the fly.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop final-third decision-making, switching of play and opportunistic finishing when multiple goals open and close.  
Scanning emphasis: Ball-carriers and off-the-ball players must scan regularly to see which goal has the green light (active) and whether any extra requirement (e.g. yellow = passes before shot) applies. Ignoring the cue and shooting at a dead goal cost the team points or possession, reinforcing the need to link scanning with timing of the final action.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 8–12 players (4v4 or 5v5)  
Area: 25m x 20m rectangular pitch.  
Players: 2 teams of 4–6 (e.g. 4v4 or 5v5).  
Equipment required: 4 small goals (one in each corner), 4 EyeQ SmartCones, 1 ball, bibs, cones for boundaries.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone placed directly behind each corner goal.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Green light behind a goal = that goal is active for scoring.  
- Players may only score in a goal that currently has a green-lit cone.  
- If a cone turns yellow, teams must complete a set number of passes (e.g. 3) after the yellow cue appears and before attempting to score in any active goal.  
- Scoring in a goal with no green light, or shooting before the required passes in a yellow phase, results in no goal (or loss of point) and a restart for the opposition.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Set up the four small goals in each corner with EyeQ cones behind them.  
2. Kick off with one team in possession in the centre of the area.  
3. Teams attack and defend as in a normal small-sided game but must scan the cones behind the goals to know where to score.  
4. At any time, one or more goals can be lit green; only these are valid targets for finishing.  
5. At random intervals, one or more cones may turn yellow, activating the pass requirement before any shot.  
6. Teams score by finishing into an active (green) goal having complied with any current yellow pass rule.  
7. After a goal or ball out of play, restart from the centre or with a goalkeeper/coach pass.  
8. Rotate players and play several short games, keeping score.

Coaching Points
- Encourage players to scan the whole pitch, including corner cones, especially before taking a shot.  
- Stress quick recognition when a new corner becomes active – can we switch play and attack it?  
- Quality of final pass and finish in small goals – accuracy over power.  
- Defenders adjust shape to protect live goals and react when cues change.  
- Communication: teammates call out “top left!”, “bottom right!” when goals light up.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Keep one goal active for longer periods so players have more time to see and attack it.  
- Easier: Remove the yellow pass requirement and focus only on green = active.  
- Harder: Require at least one switch of play (from one side to the other) before scoring in any goal.  
- Harder: Limit each player to two touches.  
- Harder: Award extra points for scoring in a goal that has only just lit and was on the far side, encouraging fast scanning and switching.

title: EyeQ Adaptive Possession Grid
overview: An advanced possession grid where EyeQ SmartCones dynamically alter the rules of play in real-time. For instance, when a cone shows red, one team might have to play one-touch; when it shows blue, the defending team gains an extra player. These unpredictable shifts force elite-level players to continuously adapt their tactics, communication and technical execution.
description:
Drill Overview
A high-intensity 6v2 possession game in a four-square grid. EyeQ SmartCones on the perimeter change colour, each colour activating a different global rule: defenders switch, attackers must break lines, or standard rules apply with a base movement constraint. Players must constantly scan and adapt their actions to the current colour.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop elite-level scanning, rapid interpretation of multiple visual cues and tactical responses in a tight possession environment.  
Scanning emphasis: Attackers must read both player positions and the perimeter colour, knowing that blue changes defenders, red enforces line-breaking passes and yellow allows standard play. Failure to scan accurately leads to broken rules and immediate role changes, embedding the habit of linking perception to action.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 8 players (6 attackers + 2 defenders, with rotations)  
Area: 16m x 16m grid, divided into four equal 8m x 8m squares.  
Players: 6 attackers inside the grid and 2 active defenders (with additional pairs ready to rotate in).  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones, 1 ball (plus spares), cones for square markings, bibs for attackers and defenders.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone centred on each sideline of the large grid, all showing the same colour at any given time.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Blue = Defensive switch: the two current defenders must immediately leave the grid and a fresh pair of defenders enters.  
- Red = Break the lines: any pass must go to a player in a different square from the passer; passes within the same square are not allowed.  
- Yellow (or no light) = Standard play: normal possession rules apply, but base rule remains – after making a pass, a player must move into a different square.  
- Incorrect responses (e.g. passing within the same square on red) result in the offending two players becoming the new defenders.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Start with the 6 attackers spread across the four inner squares and 2 defenders applying pressure.  
2. Attackers aim to keep possession, following the base rule: after passing, move into a different square.  
3. EyeQ cones shift randomly between blue, red and yellow, applying the global rules.  
4. When the light shows blue, defenders switch: they exit and a fresh defending pair quickly enters.  
5. When the light shows red, attackers must only play line-breaking passes into different squares.  
6. When the light is yellow or off, standard play continues with only the base movement rule.  
7. Any failure to obey the current colour rule or loss of possession leads to immediate consequences (e.g. offending players become defenders).  
8. Rotate defenders and attackers regularly to share load and maintain tempo.

Coaching Points
- Constantly scan for both player positions and the colour of the cones.  
- Sharpen the perceive–decide–act cycle: see colour, recall rule, scan options, then execute.  
- High technical quality: crisp passing, sharp first touch and quick, purposeful movement between squares.  
- Defenders press intelligently, especially when a new rule might catch attackers off guard.  
- Encourage anticipation: players should think “If it turns red next, where can I pass?”

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Start with only yellow (standard play) and blue (defensive switch) to get used to scanning.  
- Easier: Allow occasional “mistake resets” without changing defender roles to build confidence.  
- Harder: Increase defensive intensity and reduce grid size slightly to compress time and space.  
- Harder: Add a new colour rule (e.g. green = all players must touch the ball before a repeat pass is allowed).  
- Harder: Track and penalise repeated rule errors to emphasise concentration (e.g. 3 errors = fitness for the group).

title: Reactive Awareness Grid
overview: Players move through a grid performing different technical actions based on colour cues from EyeQ SmartCones. As they dribble, turn or pass, cones change to signal new tasks such as step-overs, change of direction, or finding a team-mate. The exercise blends ball mastery with reactive awareness, preparing players to adjust quickly to visual information while maintaining close control.
description:
Drill Overview
Pairs pass and move within a grid surrounded by randomly flashing EyeQ SmartCones. The receiver must scan for the nearest lit cone as the ball travels and adjust their first action based on its colour: driving into space, turning away from pressure or playing a one-touch combination. It turns a simple passing pattern into a multi-decision awareness drill.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop scanning habits, decision-making speed and appropriate first-touch choices based on changing visual information.  
Scanning emphasis: The receiving player must scan before the ball arrives to identify the nearest lit cone and link that colour to an action (space, pressure, combine). If they fail to scan, their first touch is likely to be inappropriate (into pressure, away from space or too slow), which is immediately obvious.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 8–16 players (pairs inside one grid)  
Area: 20m x 20m grid.  
Players: Organised in pairs, each pair with 1 ball.  
Equipment required: 8–10 EyeQ SmartCones, 1 ball per pair, cones for boundaries.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: 8–10 SmartCones placed randomly throughout or around the grid, each programmed to flash blue, red or yellow independently every 2–4 seconds.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Blue = “Space”: receive and take your first touch towards the nearest blue cone, representing moving into open space.  
- Red = “Pressure”: receive and perform a sharp turn or skill move away from the nearest red cone, simulating turning away from pressure.  
- Yellow = “Combine”: receive and play a one-touch pass straight back to your partner, simulating a quick wall pass.  
- If no cone is lit, players continue with simple receive–pass patterns without extra constraints.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Each pair starts inside the grid, passing the ball back and forth while moving.  
2. The player about to receive the ball scans to find the nearest lit EyeQ cone before the ball arrives.  
3. As they receive, they execute the action linked to that cone’s colour:
   - Blue: take first touch towards the blue cone, then pass.  
   - Red: turn sharply away from the red cone, then pass.  
   - Yellow: play a one-touch pass back to their partner.  
4. After the action, both players move to create new passing angles and repeat.  
5. Continue for 60–90 seconds, then rest briefly and rotate partners or constraints.  

Coaching Points
- Emphasise scanning before receiving, not after – “check, then control.”  
- Quality and purpose of first touch based on the cue: into space (blue) vs away from pressure (red).  
- Crisp, accurate passing and clear communication between partners.  
- Encourage continuous movement to open new angles and keep scanning fresh.  
- Use weaker foot as appropriate to build all-round capability.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Slow the cone change rate and allow two touches even on yellow (combine) at first.  
- Easier: Use only blue and yellow cues before adding red.  
- Harder: Constrain all actions to the non-dominant foot.  
- Harder: Add 1–2 floating defenders who move through the grid applying light pressure.  
- Harder: Set a time or repetition target for correctly executed cue responses (e.g. 20 blue/red/yellow actions in 2 minutes).

title: EyeQ Tactical Reactor Game 5v5
overview: A 5v5 small-sided game where EyeQ cones at different points around the pitch represent different game states such as "press high", "switch play" or "direct attack and finish". When a specific cone lights up, the team in possession must respond by transitioning into that game state immediately. The drill develops tactical flexibility and the ability to shift between styles of play on demand.
description:
Drill Overview
A 5v5 game with two goals at each end where EyeQ SmartCones around the pitch occasionally flash different colours. Each colour represents a global game state (press, switch play, one-touch finish) that both teams must immediately respect. The drill trains collective adaptation to changing tactical demands.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Train team-wide ability to recognise and react to sudden tactical shifts, including high pressing, switching play and one-touch finishing.  
Scanning emphasis: All players must constantly be aware of not only ball and opponents but also the perimeter cones. When a colour appears (red, blue, green), team behaviours must change in sync. Failing to scan results in individuals or units playing the wrong “game” inside the correct one.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 10 players (5v5)  
Area: 30m x 20m grid.  
Players: 2 teams of 5 players in different coloured bibs.  
Equipment required: 4 mini-goals (2 on each end line), 6–8 EyeQ SmartCones, several balls.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: 6–8 SmartCones around the outside perimeter; all cones show the same colour simultaneously.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- No light or steady yellow = Normal Play: standard 5v5 game, both teams trying to score.  
- All cones flash red = “High Press”: the team out of possession must execute an aggressive, collective high press until they win the ball or cue changes.  
- All cones flash blue = “Switch Play”: the team in possession must switch the ball from one vertical half to the other before they are allowed to score.  
- All cones flash green = “One-Touch Finish”: any goal scored during this period must be finished with a one-touch strike; otherwise it doesn’t count.  
- Failure to obey a game-state rule (e.g. trying to score without switching on blue) results in disallowed goals or coach-enforced turnovers.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Set up the pitch with two mini-goals on each end line and players in a 5v5 shape.  
2. Start with a normal 5v5 game under “Normal Play” state.  
3. At random intervals, the EyeQ system flashes red, blue or green on all perimeter cones.  
4. When red flashes, the out-of-possession team must immediately organise into a high press.  
5. When blue flashes, the team in possession must switch play from one side to the other before they may attempt to score.  
6. When green flashes, any goal scored must be a one-touch finish at the moment of shooting.  
7. After a set interval, lights revert to Normal Play and teams resume standard rules until the next cue.  
8. Coach keeps play flowing by serving new balls quickly when needed.

Coaching Points
- Demand constant scanning beyond the ball: players must see and react to colour changes together.  
- On red, team pressing together – compact shape, triggers and cover support.  
- On blue, encourage intelligent selection of switching method (long diagonal vs short combination).  
- On green, focus on timing of runs and quality of the set for the one-touch finish.  
- Encourage loud verbal cues from players (“Press!”, “Switch!”, “One-touch!”) when colours change.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Start by using only one cue (e.g. red = press) with all other times as Normal Play.  
- Easier: Gradually add blue, then green cues once players understand scanning concept.  
- Harder: Add specific constraints in each state (e.g. red = man-mark, blue = 2-touch max).  
- Harder: Award extra points for goals scored correctly under a cue state.  
- Harder: Increase pitch size slightly to challenge pressing and switching distances.

title: Reactive 2v1 Shooting
overview: A 2v1 shooting exercise where attackers combine to create a shooting opportunity, but EyeQ SmartCones behind the goal determine which attacker is allowed to shoot. As the attack develops, the active shooter may change, forcing rapid decision-making and creative interplay to get the ball to the correct player before the chance is lost.
description:
Drill Overview
A 2v1 (or 2v2) finishing pattern where one attacker receives with back to goal under pressure and must scan an EyeQ cone as the pass travels. The cone colour dictates whether they lay the ball off, turn to shoot or switch the ball into wide mini-goals, forcing quick, cue-driven decisions in the final third.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Train attackers to scan cues while receiving, then choose the correct action (lay-off, turn, switch) in a realistic finishing situation.  
Scanning emphasis: The receiving attacker must read the EyeQ cone as the ball is en route, not after control. Blue means one action, red another, yellow a third; if they fail to scan, they’ll choose the wrong response and the chance breaks down, clearly linking visual attention to outcome.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 3–4 players per station (2 attackers + 1–2 defenders)  
Area: 25m x 20m grid in front of a full-size or medium goal.  
Players: 3 players per station – Attacker A (server), Attacker B (receiver), Defender C (pressing defender). Optionally add a fourth defender for higher challenge.  
Equipment required: 1 EyeQ SmartCone, 1 main goal, 2 mini-goals placed wide near the goal line, a supply of balls.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone positioned near or behind the central goal, clearly in B’s line of sight.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Blue = “Lay-off”: defender is tight; B lays the ball off first-time for A to run onto and shoot.  
- Red = “Turn”: space to attack; B receives, turns and drives at goal 1v1 vs defender before shooting.  
- Yellow = “Switch”: central lane blocked; B plays a 1-touch pass into either wide mini-goal, representing a switch to a wide player.  
- Using an incorrect action for the colour (e.g. turning on blue) is treated as an error; reset or let play continue but highlight decision.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Player A starts at the top of the grid with the ball; B is positioned centrally, back to goal, with C marking from behind or side.  
2. A passes firmly into B’s feet to start the pattern.  
3. As the ball travels, the EyeQ cone flashes blue, red or yellow.  
4. B scans the cone and, on receiving, immediately performs the action linked to that colour:
   - Blue: one-touch lay-off into A’s path for a shot on the main goal.  
   - Red: control, turn and drive at goal 1v1, then shoot.  
   - Yellow: one-touch pass into either wide mini-goal.  
5. A and C react accordingly – A supports shots or rebounds, C defends realistically.  
6. After each repetition, rotate roles so all players experience A, B and C positions.  
7. Repeat for a set number of repetitions on each colour or in a mixed random sequence.

Coaching Points
- B’s body shape: open stance to see both the incoming ball and the EyeQ cone.  
- Early scan: decision should be made before the first touch.  
- Quality of A’s pass – weight and accuracy to give B realistic options.  
- Realistic defending from C to keep intensity high without reckless tackling.  
- Encourage confident finishing and quick reactions, not hesitation.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Begin with only one colour cue active (e.g. blue = lay-off) to groove the pattern.  
- Easier: Reduce defender pressure or make C semi-passive.  
- Harder: Activate two colours (blue and red), then all three to increase decision complexity.  
- Harder: Add a second defender to create a 2v2 and increase defensive information B must read.  
- Harder: Add a scoring system where correct colour–action decisions plus goals earn extra points.
