title: Reactive Game States
overview: Teams play in a confined area where EyeQ SmartCones signal changes in game state. When a cone lights up, the team must decide whether to attack immediately or hold possession and wait for a better opportunity. Different colours represent scenarios like counter-attack mode, patient build-up or defensive transition. The exercise sharpens collective decision-making and tactical discipline.
description:
Drill Overview
A 3v3 possession game where the global “game state” constantly changes based on the EyeQ cone colour around the pitch. Blue means keep the ball, red means attack the mini-goals, and yellow locks the ball-carrier into shielding. Players must continually scan the lights and instantly adapt their behaviour to the current state.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop players’ ability to maintain possession under pressure while quickly switching between keeping the ball, attacking goal and shielding.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must scan not only for team-mates and defenders but also the perimeter cones before and during each action. They must recognise the current colour/game state and execute the correct behaviour; failing to scan leads directly to using the wrong tactic (e.g. holding the ball when they should attack, or passing when they should shield).

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 6–8 players (3v3 plus optional neutral)  
Area: 25m x 20m grid.  
Players: 3v3 inside the grid (add a neutral joker for advanced levels).  
Equipment required: 6 EyeQ SmartCones around the perimeter, 2 mini-goals on one end line, 1 ball, bibs.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Six SmartCones spaced evenly around the outside of the grid; all show the same colour at any one time.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Blue = “Keep Ball”: team in possession plays standard 3v3 keep-away, aiming for a target number of passes (e.g. 5) to score a point.  
- Red = “Attack Goal”: team in possession must immediately attack and try to score in either mini-goal.  
- Yellow = “Player Locked”: the player on the ball must shield and cannot pass or dribble away; team-mates move to provide options for when the colour changes.  
- Breaking a game-state rule (e.g. trying to score on blue, or passing on yellow) or losing possession under pressure results in a turnover; new team in possession now follows the cue.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Set up the grid with 3v3 inside and two mini-goals at one end.  
2. Start with the EyeQ pattern running in the background, cycling through blue, red and yellow.  
3. Begin play with a coach pass; the team receiving starts in possession.  
4. When cones are blue, the team in possession plays keep-ball, chasing the target pass count.  
5. When cones flip to red, they must instantly transition to attack and try to score in a mini-goal while opponents drop to defend.  
6. When cones turn yellow, the current ball-carrier locks into shielding and must protect the ball until the state changes, while team-mates move to create options.  
7. After any goal, ball out or clear turnover, restart with a coach pass and continue with the ongoing EyeQ pattern.  
8. Rotate players and, at higher levels, add a neutral joker to create 4v3 when in possession.

Coaching Points
- “Head up”: players should scan cones regularly, especially before receiving.  
- Demand instant behavioural change when colours switch – no delay.  
- On blue: emphasise support angles, body shape to receive and sharp two-touch passing.  
- On red: “forward first” mentality – positive runs, quick combinations and finishing.  
- On yellow: strong shielding technique and good support movement from team-mates.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Level 1 – only react to blue (keep ball) and red (attack), ignore yellow (play continues in previous state).  
- Standard: Level 2 – all three colours active: blue = keep ball, red = attack, yellow = player locked.  
- Harder: Level 3 – keep same states but make blue play 2-touch only for attackers.  
- Harder: Level 4 – add a neutral joker to create 4v3 in possession, increasing scanning and decision demands.

title: Trapped Until Colour - Box Release Rondo
overview: A box-shaped rondo where attackers maintain possession but cannot pass to certain "trapped" team-mates until an EyeQ SmartCone in that player's zone lights up in the correct colour. Once freed, that player becomes an active passing option again. The drill teaches patience, scanning for open players and precise distribution under the constraint of shifting available targets.
description:
Drill Overview
Three attackers keep the ball inside a square against two defenders but are “trapped” until an EyeQ gate lights. Each side of the square has a gate with different colour rules; once a gate lights, the team in possession must scan, identify the colour and escape through the correct gate with the correct action.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve ball retention under pressure and the timing of breakouts through scanning and reacting to cues.  
Scanning emphasis: Attackers must constantly scan both defenders and the four EyeQ gates, then adjust quickly when a colour appears. If they rush through the wrong gate, go too early, or use the wrong action, the defenders are rewarded, underlining the importance of checking the cue.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 5–7 players (3 attackers + 2 defenders)  
Area: 20m x 20m square.  
Players: 3 attackers vs 2 defenders inside the square; coach on the side with spare balls.  
Equipment required: 8 EyeQ SmartCones (4 gates made from 2 cones each), 8–10 flat markers for area, 2–3 balls.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: On the middle of each side of the square, create a 2m gate with two SmartCones; each gate can show a different colour.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- When cones at one gate light, that is the only active escape gate.  
- Red gate = team must dribble through that gate to escape.  
- Green gate = team must pass through the gate with a team-mate receiving on the far side.  
- Other colours or no light = no escape allowed; attackers must keep possession inside the square.  
- Leaving early, using the wrong action for the gate colour, or escaping through a non-lit gate = automatic turnover and defenders gain a point.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Set up the square and four EyeQ gates; place 3 attackers and 2 defenders inside.  
2. Coach serves a ball into the attackers, who aim to keep possession under pressure.  
3. Attackers may not leave the square until a gate lights.  
4. When a gate’s SmartCones light up, the team in possession must quickly scan, identify the gate colour and direction, and execute the correct escape:
   - Red: work the ball to dribble through that gate.  
   - Green: find a pass through that gate to a supporting attacker on the far side.  
5. If they succeed in escaping correctly, award them a point and reset with a new ball.  
6. If they choose the wrong gate, act before any gate lights, or use the wrong action, the defenders gain a point and the coach resets play.  
7. Rotate roles so players experience both attacking and defending.

Coaching Points
- Encourage attackers to stay calm under pressure – good angles, short passes, supportive movement.  
- Link scanning to the cue: “see pressure, see support, quick check on gates.”  
- Emphasise half-turned body shape to see as much of the box as possible.  
- Communication around gate colours (“Red gate!”, “Green pass!”) to support decision-making.  
- Defenders should press smartly and be ready to pounce when attackers hesitate.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Use only one gate colour at first (e.g. all gates = same dribble rule) to learn the concept.  
- Easier: Allow attackers to escape through any lit gate regardless of colour, then add colour-specific actions later.  
- Harder: Add a third defender or slightly shrink the area.  
- Harder: Add a rule that defenders can counter-score by dribbling through any non-lit gate after a regain.

title: Chaos Shooting Challenge
overview: An intense finishing drill where multiple shooting stations are set up, each marked by an EyeQ SmartCone. Players start from a central zone with a ball and must sprint to whichever station lights up, arriving in time to take a shot before the cone switches off. If they arrive too late, they must react instantly and sprint to the new active station. The exercise builds explosive power, decision speed and composure under fatigue.
description:
Drill Overview
Attackers receive passes around the edge of the box while three goals (one big, two small) are linked to EyeQ SmartCones. At any moment, only the goal with the lit cone is “live” and sometimes the cone colour also dictates the finishing technique. Attackers must scan, pick the correct target and use an appropriate technique under defensive pressure.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop rapid scanning, target selection and varied finishing techniques in a chaotic final-third environment.  
Scanning emphasis: As the ball travels from server to attacker, the attacker must scan all three cones to see which goal is live and what colour/technique is required. If they fail to scan, they’ll attack the wrong goal or use the wrong finish and the attempt won’t count, making scanning a non-negotiable.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 6–10 players (attackers + 1–2 defenders + GK)  
Area: Final third around the penalty area.  
Players: Several attackers working in rotation, 1–2 live defenders, 1 server (coach or player), and a goalkeeper in the big goal if available.  
Equipment required: 1 full-size goal, 2 small goals set at angles near the edges of the box, 3 EyeQ SmartCones (one by each goal), a large supply of balls.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone next to each goal. Cones are set to a repeating pattern where only one cone is lit at any time in varying colours.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
Base rule:
- The goal with the lit cone is the only live target for that repetition.  

Progressions:
- If-Then technique:  
  - Blue cone = finish with one touch.  
  - Green cone = take two or more touches before shooting.  
- Go/No-Go:  
  - Green = “Go” – attacker may shoot at the lit goal.  
  - Red = “No-Go” – that goal is blocked; attacker must dribble and score in one of the other (unlit) goals or any other green-lit goal.  
- Using the wrong target or technique for the given colour results in no goal being awarded.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Server stands centrally 20–25 yards from the large goal with a supply of balls.  
2. First attacker starts in an agreed starting area; defender(s) position realistically.  
3. Server plays a pass into the attacker’s path.  
4. As the ball travels, one EyeQ cone lights at one of the three goals.  
5. Attacker scans to identify which goal is live and what, if any, colour rule applies.  
6. Under pressure from the defender(s), the attacker must drive and finish into the correct live goal with the required technique.  
7. After the attempt, players rotate attacker/defender roles or return to the queue.  
8. Continue with a fixed pattern or random sequence of cone activations.

Coaching Points
- “Scan before you receive” – players should know their target before first touch.  
- Adaptive first touch that opens body toward the live goal and sets up the chosen finish.  
- Selection of finishing technique: powerful, high finishes for the big goal; precise, placed finishes for small goals.  
- Encourage calm decisions despite pressure; don’t rush just because the cone is lit.  
- Defenders apply realistic pressure, forcing quick but composed decisions.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Run without defenders initially so players can focus on scanning and technique.  
- Easier: Treat any lit cone as simply “shoot at that goal”, regardless of colour.  
- Harder: Activate the If-Then technique layer (colour dictates number of touches).  
- Harder: Introduce Go/No-Go logic so attackers must sometimes ignore the lit goal and choose a different target.  
- Harder: Add a second defender or require attackers to beat a man before shooting in certain colours.

title: Dynamic Gate Discovery
overview: Players dribble in a grid filled with small gates made from pairs of EyeQ SmartCones. Gates light up randomly; players must spot the active gate, dribble through it quickly, then hunt for the next one. The gates can switch off mid-approach, forcing players to change direction and search for a new target. The exercise improves scanning, agility and ball control under dynamic visual pressure.
description:
Drill Overview
A 3v3 possession game inside a hexagon of EyeQ gates, supported by 1–2 roaming neutrals on the outside. At any time, one gate (pair of cones) is live, indicated by a light; neutrals must sprint to that gate, and the team in possession must find a way to pass through it to the neutral to score.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve team possession, awareness of shifting targets and coordination between inside and outside players.  
Scanning emphasis: Central players and neutrals must both scan the cones constantly. Inside players look to identify which gate is live and whether a neutral is arriving; neutrals must watch for light changes and sprint to the new gate. If either group fails to scan, passes are mistimed or gates are attacked without support.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 6–8 players (3v3 inside + 1–2 neutrals outside)  
Area: Hexagon created with 6 gates or a circular area approximating a hexagon.  
Players: 3v3 inside the hexagon; 1–2 neutrals on the outside.  
Equipment required: 6 EyeQ SmartCones forming 6 gates (one cone per gate) plus extra markers for shape, 1 ball (plus spares).  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Six SmartCones placed evenly around to form six narrow “gates” at the perimeter; cones light one at a time (or occasionally two) in a set rhythm of every 4–6 seconds.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Only the gate whose cone is currently lit is active and can be used to score.  
- To score, the team in possession must pass the ball through the lit gate to a neutral player who has moved to that gate.  
- A pass through any non-lit gate, or through a lit gate with no neutral there, is a misfire and results in a turnover.  
- When a new gate lights, the previous one is no longer active even if a neutral is still there.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Set up the hexagon of gates with 3 attackers and 3 defenders inside, and 1–2 neutrals roaming outside.  
2. Play begins with a coach pass to one of the inside teams, who try to keep possession.  
3. EyeQ cones light one gate at a time; neutrals must scan and move quickly to the lit gate to offer a passing option.  
4. The team in possession scans to identify the live gate and which neutral is best positioned.  
5. When the moment is right, they play a pass through the lit gate into the neutral’s feet to score a point.  
6. If they score, they retain possession and play continues with the next light change.  
7. If they misfire or defenders win the ball, possession changes and the other team now tries to score through the live gate.  
8. Rotate roles regularly so all players experience inside and neutral positions.

Coaching Points
- Inside players: frequent shoulder checks to see both gates and neutrals.  
- Neutrals: pro-active movement towards newly lit gates; arrive on time, not late.  
- Emphasise communication (“Gate left”, “Red gate!”, “I’m here”) between inside and outside players.  
- Encourage patience – don’t force passes when no neutral is in position.  
- Defenders react to gate changes, pressing to block the line to the lit gate.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Keep gates lit for longer and slow down light changes.  
- Easier: Allow two active gates at once to give more scoring options.  
- Harder: Always light two gates; team must decide which is the better option.  
- Harder: After scoring, the passer swaps with the neutral receiver (pass & replace), encouraging constant role change.  
- Harder: Add a 5-second limit once a gate lights – if no score in time, automatic turnover.

title: Virus Hunters
overview: A fun, tag-based game where certain players are designated "viruses" who try to tag healthy players. EyeQ SmartCones around the area change colour to show safe zones where healthy players cannot be tagged. As colours shift, safe zones move and players must sprint to new sanctuaries. The game develops speed, spatial awareness and quick reaction in a playful, competitive format ideal for younger groups.
description:
Drill Overview
A fun tag-style game where all players dribble in a square and EyeQ SmartCones decide which colour group becomes the “Hunters”. The Hunters try to tag others while dribbling; on the next colour change, new Hunters appear and the tagged players are released.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve dribbling, evasion and awareness in a fun, game-based setting.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must keep their head up to spot which bib colour is currently the Hunter group and where those players are moving. If they focus only on their ball, they are more likely to be tagged; scanning helps them find space and avoid danger.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 6–12 players (one ball each)  
Area: 15m x 15m square (scale with age and numbers).  
Players: 6–8 players per grid (use two grids for larger groups), split into equal groups with red, green and blue bibs; each player has a ball.  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones, 1 ball per player, bibs.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Four SmartCones at the midpoint of each side of the square.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- The colour showing on the EyeQ cone indicates which bib colour group are the Hunters.  
- When the cone is red, red-bib players become Hunters; green for green-bib Hunters; blue for blue-bib Hunters.  
- Hunters must dribble their own ball while trying to tag other players with their free hand or by gently touching their shoulder.  
- Tagged players freeze in place with their ball until the next colour change, when a new Hunter group is selected and previously tagged players are released.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. All players dribble freely in the grid with a ball.  
2. At set intervals (e.g. every 8–10 seconds), an EyeQ cone lights red, green or blue.  
3. The matching bib group instantly becomes Hunters and tries to tag as many other players as possible while still dribbling.  
4. Tagged players stop moving and stand with their ball at their feet.  
5. When the colour changes, the previous Hunters stop hunting and resume normal dribbling; frozen players are released and the new bib colour becomes Hunters.  
6. Continue through many cycles, keeping it fast and playful.

Coaching Points
- Encourage players to dribble with their head up, not staring at the ball.  
- Emphasise big touches into space when far from Hunters; small, tight touches when near pressure.  
- Hunters should dribble under control while hunting, not just sprinting without the ball.  
- Reinforce scanning the cones and bib colours to anticipate who might become Hunter next.  
- Keep energy high and fun – lots of encouragement and quick resets.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow Hunters to tag without having to dribble, then progress to dribbling required.  
- Easier: Increase the grid size to give more space.  
- Harder: Allow Hunters to knock balls away instead of tagging; players whose ball is knocked out must do a quick skill (e.g. 5 toe taps) before re-joining.  
- Harder: Add a second cone colour state where two bib groups are Hunters at once to increase chaos.

title: Spot the Runner and Pass
overview: A possession game where several "runners" move continuously around the outside of the playing area. EyeQ SmartCones in each runner's zone light up to indicate when that runner is available for a pass. The team in possession must scan the perimeter, spot the active runner and deliver an accurate pass out to them before the cone switches off. This improves peripheral vision, timing of passes and support play.
description:
Drill Overview
Four players combine in a passing grid while four EyeQ cones at the far end each belong to a specific player. When a cone lights, the assigned player must make a sharp forward run, and the team-mate on the ball must scan, spot the run and play an early through pass into space.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve timing and quality of forward runs and through passes from simple possession play.  
Scanning emphasis: All players, particularly the one in possession, must scan for light cues and identify which player has been triggered to run. Failing to scan leaves the runner unserved or leads to late, inaccurate passes.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 4 players (3 in grid + 1 runner, or 4 rotating)  
Area: 20m wide x 30m long rectangle; main passing happens in the nearer 20m x 20m zone.  
Players: 4 players working as a group.  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones, 1 ball (plus spares), markers for grid.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Four SmartCones placed in a line at the far end of the grid, one assigned to each player; each cone has a distinct colour linked to its player.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Each player is assigned a specific colour and EyeQ cone (e.g. blue, red, green, yellow).  
- When one EyeQ cone lights, only the player assigned to that colour must immediately make a forward run into space.  
- The player in possession must scan, recognise which cone lit and find the corresponding runner with a through pass into their path.  
- Ignoring the runner or misreading the colour (passing to the wrong player) means the attempt doesn’t count; simply reset and continue passing.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. All 4 players start inside the main 20m x 20m grid, passing freely.  
2. Coach or EyeQ pattern activates one of the four cones at random intervals.  
3. As soon as a cone lights, the player assigned to that colour reacts by making a sharp forward run beyond the grid.  
4. The player currently in possession scans, spots the runner and plays an early through pass into their path.  
5. The runner controls the ball in stride, then passes it back into the grid to a team-mate.  
6. All four players recover into the grid and resume the passing sequence until the next cue.  
7. Rotate colours or player positions regularly to share running and passing roles.

Coaching Points
- Constant scanning while passing – not just when you have the ball.  
- Timing of the run: explosive movement as soon as the cone lights, staying onside if used in a directional context.  
- Through pass weight: ahead of the runner, into space they can attack.  
- Good first touch from the runner to secure the ball before playing back.  
- Clear communication – shout colour and name when cones light.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Remove distance and let the runner receive just outside the grid.  
- Easier: Slow change rate so players are not rushed.  
- Harder: Limit passes in the grid to one- or two-touch to increase tempo.  
- Harder: Add a passive defender in the grid who can intercept poorly timed or inaccurate through passes.  
- Harder: Require the runner to finish on goal instead of passing back if you add a target goal.

title: Pass to Neutral or 1-Touch
overview: Attackers maintain possession in a grid with a neutral player positioned centrally. EyeQ SmartCones dictate whether the next pass must go to the neutral (one colour) or be a direct one-touch pass between attackers (another colour). Players must scan the cone, make the correct decision instantly and execute with precision. The drill enhances quick thinking, ball speed and cooperative play.
description:
Drill Overview
Two teams and two neutral players share a big possession square. Teams can always use the neutrals, but only when the EyeQ cone near a neutral matches their team colour; otherwise they must play around them. This forces constant scanning of both neutrals and colour cues, and encourages smart use of overloads.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve build-up play using neutrals, as well as decision-making about when and how to use support based on visual cues.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must scan both the field and the EyeQ corner cones to know when a neutral is “live” for their team. If they ignore the cue, they either miss advantages or break the rule by using a neutral when their colour isn’t showing.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 14 players (6v6 plus 2 neutrals)  
Area: 30m x 30m square.  
Players: 2 teams of 6 (Team A and Team B) plus 2 neutrals who play for the team in possession when allowed.  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones at the corners, several balls, bibs for both teams and neutrals.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone at each corner of the square; cones light in different colours corresponding to team colours (e.g. green for Team A, blue for Team B).

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Each team is assigned a colour (e.g. Team A = green, Team B = blue).  
- Neutrals are only “live” for a team when the cone nearest them shows that team’s colour.  
- If Team A’s colour is lit at a corner nearest a neutral, Team A can pass to that neutral; Team B may not use that neutral at that moment.  
- If no cone near a neutral matches a team’s colour, that team must keep possession using only their own players.  
- Passing illegally to a neutral when their colour is not showing = turnover.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Set up the square and place the two neutrals inside; assign colours to Team A and Team B.  
2. Both teams start with a ball to warm up passing, then switch to a single ball to compete.  
3. Teams try to keep possession, with the option of using neutrals when allowed by the current cue.  
4. EyeQ cones change colours at unpredictable intervals.  
5. Players must scan to see when the cone near a neutral matches their team colour and then use that neutral to create overloads.  
6. When possession changes, the new team in possession immediately uses the same cue rules.  
7. Play in timed blocks, then rotate neutrals and team roles.

Coaching Points
- Encourage players to scan neutrals and corner cones while moving, not just after receiving.  
- Emphasise clever use of neutrals: bounce passes, switch of play, and breaking pressure.  
- Highlight anticipation of colour changes – players should be ready to use a neutral as soon as they become live.  
- Stress quick decision-making and communication when a cue appears (“Green neutral live!”).  
- Maintain good team shape to support the ball with width and depth.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Let neutrals be always available to both teams while players get used to scanning.  
- Easier: Use only one neutral initially.  
- Harder: Introduce one-touch or two-touch passing for the team in possession.  
- Harder: Award points for using a neutral and then breaking a line directly after.  
- Harder: Add a scoring system with mini-goals that can only be attacked after a successful neutral link-up when your colour is lit.

title: 4 Runners Outside of Square
overview: Four runners are positioned outside a square, one on each side. A team inside the square keeps possession while EyeQ SmartCones indicate which outside runner is currently active. The team must pass to the correct runner, who then plays the ball back in for the team to continue possession. Successful sequences score points. The exercise develops outward vision, passing accuracy and coordinated movement.
description:
Drill Overview
Inside players keep the ball in a square while four outside players jog around the perimeter. EyeQ SmartCones at the corners light in colours that match outside players’ bibs; inside players must scan for lit cones and outside players of that colour to pick the correct moment and target for a penetrating pass.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve awareness of support players outside the main play area and the timing of passes into them.  
Scanning emphasis: Inside players must constantly scan cones and outside runners; when a cone lights, they must identify an outside player with matching bib colour and decide whether to pass out or keep the ball if no match exists. Failure to scan leads to wrong choices or missed opportunities.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 9–12 players (5–8 inside + 4 outside)  
Area: 20m x 20m square.  
Players: 5–8 players inside the square; 4 players outside jogging around the perimeter.  
Equipment required: 4 EyeQ SmartCones (one at each corner), supply of balls, coloured bibs for all players (colours overlapping with cone options).  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone on each corner; each can light in different colours that correspond to outside players’ bibs.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- When a corner cone lights in a colour, it signals that outside players wearing that colour bib are now valid targets.  
- An inside player may pass to any outside player whose bib matches the lit colour.  
- If no outside player’s bib matches the lit colour, inside players must keep possession.  
- Passing to an outside player when their colour is not currently lit = error; reset or treat as turnover.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Arrange inside players in the grid, playing keep-ball with one or two balls.  
2. Four outside runners jog steadily around the perimeter, staying available.  
3. EyeQ cones light randomly in different colours at the corners.  
4. When a cone lights, inside players must scan to find a matching-colour outside runner and decide if a pass is on.  
5. An inside player passes out to a matching outside runner, who has up to two touches to control and pass the ball back into the grid to a different inside player.  
6. Inside players regain possession and continue passing until the next cue.  
7. Rotate roles so different players experience inside and outside roles.

Coaching Points
- Inside players: frequent scanning of corners and outside players, not just team-mates inside.  
- Body position and first touch that allow quick switching of play to an outside runner.  
- Quality and timing of the pass – into the runner’s stride and away from pressure.  
- Outside players: be alert, adjust jogging to be available when your colour lights.  
- Encourage communication (“Blue outside!”, “Green runner free!”).

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Use fewer colours and slow down cone changes.  
- Easier: Allow inside players to pass to any outside player regardless of colour at first.  
- Harder: Limit inside players to two touches to increase speed of recognition and play.  
- Harder: Add a second ball inside the grid.  
- Harder: After passing out, inside passer swaps roles with the outside runner to create constant rotation.

title: Trapped Until Colour - Advanced Version
overview: A more complex version of the "Trapped Until Colour" concept for advanced players. Multiple zones contain trapped attackers who can only be released when their zone's EyeQ cone shows a specific colour. The possessing team must monitor several cones simultaneously, decide optimal passing sequences and execute under defensive pressure. The drill challenges multi-tasking, spatial awareness and decision hierarchy.
description:
Drill Overview
A more complex version of Trapped Until Colour: attackers and defenders play 3v2 inside a square with four fixed coloured gates and four corner EyeQ cones. Attackers are trapped until the EyeQ cones show a colour; then they must scan and escape through the gate whose colour matches the cue, while defenders try to win the ball or counter.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Refine scanning and decision speed under pressure with a fixed spatial layout of gates that map directly onto light cues.  
Scanning emphasis: Attackers must continually check all four corner cones, ready to move as soon as a colour appears. They must link that colour to its gate location and coordinate the escape. Defenders also scan, especially in the progression where they counter through gates that do *not* match the cue.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 5 players (3 attackers + 2 defenders)  
Area: 20m x 20m square.  
Players: 3 attackers vs 2 defenders; coach on the sideline.  
Equipment required: 4 coloured plastic gates (red, blue, yellow, green) placed at the midpoint of each side, 4 EyeQ SmartCones in the corners, flat markers for the square, 1–2 balls.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: One SmartCone at each corner; these provide only the colour cue and are not gates themselves.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Red = escape through the red gate (left side).  
- Blue = escape through the blue gate (top side).  
- Yellow = escape through the yellow gate (right side).  
- Green = escape through the green gate (bottom side).  
- Black / off = no gate is live; attackers must stay inside the square.  
- Leaving before a colour appears, or escaping through the wrong-coloured gate, is a turnover and a point for defenders.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Coach starts the EyeQ light pattern and serves a ball into the attackers.  
2. Attackers play 3v2, keeping the ball inside the square and not crossing the lines until a cue appears.  
3. When the EyeQ cones all show a colour, attackers quickly scan corners to identify which colour is active.  
4. The team in possession then works together to escape through the gate that matches the cue colour, either by dribbling or passing.  
5. On a successful escape, attackers score a point; coach resets play with a new ball.  
6. If attackers leave early, go through the wrong gate or lose possession, defenders gain a point.  
7. In progression, if defenders win the ball, they attempt to escape through any gate *not* matching the cue colour to earn a bonus point.  
8. Rotate players between attacking and defending roles.

Coaching Points
- Frequent scanning of all four corners between touches; don’t fixate on one gate.  
- Half-turned body shape to see as much of the pitch and cues as possible.  
- Quick, decisive acceleration once the correct gate is identified.  
- Communication – clear calls (“Blue gate!”, “Green bottom!”) to synchronise escape.  
- Defenders should anticipate likely escape paths and press to block them.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Remove the colour–gate mapping and allow escape through any gate when a colour appears.  
- Easier: Play 3v1 instead of 3v2 to create more success for attackers.  
- Harder: Add a third defender or make gates narrower.  
- Harder: Give defenders a counter condition: if they escape correctly before attackers, their points double.  
- Harder: Introduce a time limit (e.g. 5 seconds) to escape once the colour appears.

title: Traffic Light Decision
overview: An attack vs defence transition game where an EyeQ SmartCone acts as a traffic light. Green means the attacking team can push forward freely; amber means hold possession and probe; red means they must retreat and recycle the ball to defenders. The defending team responds to the same signals by adjusting their pressing intensity. The exercise trains collective game management and transitions based on real-time information.
description:
Drill Overview
An attacker receives a pass in a channel leading to goal while EyeQ SmartCones show a “traffic light” colour. The colour dictates whether the striker must shoot immediately, combine with a support player or dribble 1v1 before finishing, training fast cue-based decisions in the final third.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve final-third decision-making and execution – shoot, combine or dribble – based on a simple visual cue.  
Scanning emphasis: The striker must scan the three SmartCones as the ball is played in and identify the colour before their first action. If they don’t scan, they’re likely to choose the wrong option or hesitate, which is quickly exposed by the defender and visible in the outcome.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 3–4 players per station (striker, support, defender, GK optional)  
Area: 25m x 20m channel leading into a goal.  
Players: 1 striker, 1 support player, 1 defender and 1 goalkeeper (optional) per station.  
Equipment required: 3 EyeQ SmartCones, standard cones to mark the channel, 1 goal, several balls.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Three SmartCones positioned ahead of the striker, within the striker’s eyeline (e.g. near or behind the goal).

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Red = Shoot: striker must take a quick shot on goal as soon as possible after receiving.  
- Green = Pass and combine: striker must pass to the support player and then receive a return pass (one-two) before shooting.  
- Blue = Dribble: striker must drive at and attempt to beat the defender 1v1 before getting a shot away.  
- Using the wrong action for the colour (e.g. dribbling on red) is treated as an error; coach highlights and quickly resets.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Server (coach or support player) starts with balls at the top of the channel.  
2. Striker stands in the channel with an open body shape, defender positioned between them and the goal.  
3. Server plays a pass into the striker.  
4. As the ball travels, one of the three EyeQ cones lights red, green or blue.  
5. The striker scans, identifies the colour and immediately executes the corresponding action:
   - Red: control if needed and shoot quickly.  
   - Green: play into the support player, then spin or move to receive the return pass and shoot.  
   - Blue: drive at the defender to create and take a 1v1 before finishing.  
6. After the shot, players reset and rotate roles after a set number of reps.  
7. Repeat with mixed colour cues to keep decisions unpredictable.

Coaching Points
- Emphasise scanning across all three cones as the pass arrives, not after controlling.  
- Encourage a positive, decisive first touch that suits the required action.  
- Reinforce appropriate finishing technique – quality over power, especially after combinations or dribbles.  
- Defender should adjust pressure based on action but keep it realistic and competitive.  
- Communication between striker and support player, especially for green (pass and combine).

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Start with only one colour active at a time (e.g. only red = shoot) to groove patterns.  
- Easier: Remove the defender initially to focus on cue reading and execution.  
- Harder: Add a second defender turning the scenario into 2v2 when green or blue appears.  
- Harder: Add a time limit to finish after the cue (e.g. 4 seconds).  
- Harder: Award extra points for correct decision + goal combinations and track scores over multiple rounds.

title: 3-Goal Challenge
overview: Three small goals are positioned around a playing area, each assigned a different point value indicated by EyeQ SmartCones. Teams compete to score in the goals, but the values change periodically. Players must constantly scan all three goals, assess which is worth the most points at any moment and attack accordingly. The drill develops strategic awareness, rapid re-assessment and decision-making under competitive pressure.
description:
Drill Overview
A 5v5 directional game where three EyeQ SmartCones on each end line define which “goal line segment” is live. Only the segment behind the red-lit cone can be used to score by passing or dribbling over the line. Teams must constantly scan the far end line, then attack or defend the currently active scoring channel.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve scanning for distant cues, forward-looking decision-making and coordinated attacking runs towards a moving scoring target.  
Scanning emphasis: On every regain, the ball-carrier and team-mates must quickly lift their heads to find the red-lit cone on the far end line. If they attack the wrong segment or fail to notice a change, any “goal” is disallowed and play restarts, making scanning for the red cone essential, not optional.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 10 players (5v5)  
Area: 35m x 25m rectangular pitch.  
Players: 2 teams of 5 (5v5).  
Equipment required: 6 EyeQ SmartCones (3 on each end line), flat markers for pitch, bibs, 1–2 balls.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Three SmartCones evenly spaced along each end line; the lit cone marks the active scoring segment on that line.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Red-lit cone = that specific scoring segment is active on that end line.  
- To score, the ball must be passed or dribbled over the goal line in the zone directly behind the red-lit cone.  
- Only one red-lit cone is active at any time.  
- Any “goal” scored in a non-red segment, or while no segment is lit, does not count and results in an immediate restart for the opposition.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Organise two teams of 5 and place them on the pitch in balanced shapes.  
2. Start play with a pass-in from the coach or a simple kick-off.  
3. The team in possession attacks the opponent’s end line, scanning for which of the three cones on that line is lit red.  
4. They attempt to pass or dribble over the goal line behind the red-lit cone to score a point.  
5. If possession changes, the new team immediately attacks the opposite end line and must scan that side for the red cone.  
6. If a team carries or passes over the line in the wrong segment, the “goal” is disallowed and the opponent restarts play from their own half.  
7. Play for several short games (e.g. 3–4 minutes) and keep score.

Coaching Points
- Constant scanning, especially just after winning the ball – “Where is the red light?”  
- Body shape so the ball-carrier can see up the pitch and towards the far end line.  
- Encourage smart use of width and depth to attack the live channel, not just straight lines.  
- Defenders adjust to protect the active scoring segment but be ready to re-adjust if the cone changes.  
- Clear communication from all players when the active segment moves (“Left red!”, “Right red!”).

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow scoring at either end line when any cone is red, to reduce complexity.  
- Easier: Keep the red cone active for longer periods before switching.  
- Harder: Add a requirement that at least one pass must be played into wide space before entering the active scoring channel.  
- Harder: Restrict the team in possession to two touches per player.  
- Harder: Add bonus points for scoring quickly (e.g. within 5 seconds of regaining possession).

title: Three Mission Game
overview: A small-sided game where EyeQ SmartCones display three different "missions" that teams must achieve in sequence, such as: (1) complete five passes, (2) switch the ball across the pitch, (3) score in a specific goal. Only after completing mission one can the team attempt mission two, and so on. The drill combines tactical objectives, builds composure under constraints and rewards teams that can read, remember and execute layered tasks.
description:
Drill Overview
A 5v5 game on half a pitch with one big goal and two wide mini-goals. Three EyeQ SmartCones near the big goal show colour combinations that define different “missions”: attack big goal, link with a neutral target then finish, or switch play and score in wide mini-goals. Players must constantly scan the cones and adjust how they attack.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Train players to quickly interpret changing visual cues and adapt their attacking strategy – direct play, link-up or switch – in realistic 5v5 scenarios.  
Scanning emphasis: After each turnover, the ball-carrier must re-scan the three cones by the big goal to identify the current mission colour, then scan for the relevant target (big goal, neutral, or mini-goals). Failure to scan leads to attacking the wrong target and disallowed goals, making cue reading and re-scanning on each regain vital.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 10 outfield players (5v5) + 1 goalkeeper + 1 neutral target  
Area: Half a full-size pitch.  
Players: 2 teams of 5 outfield players (5v5), 1 goalkeeper in the big goal, 1 neutral target player on halfway.  
Equipment required: 1 full-size goal with GK, 2 mini-goals on the halfway line (one wide on each side), 3 EyeQ SmartCones, bibs, 4–6 balls.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Three SmartCones in a visible line behind or beside the big goal; these display the current mission colour / combination.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Red = Mission 1 – Big Goal: team in possession must attack and score in the big goal.  
- Red + Green (combined pattern) = Mission 2 – Target then Big Goal: before scoring in the big goal, team must play a pass to the neutral target player on halfway, who sets the ball back or switches it.  
- Blue = Mission 3 – Switch to Mini-Goals: team in possession must switch play and score in either mini-goal on the halfway line (by pass or dribble).  
- Goals scored that do not follow the current mission (e.g. big goal on blue, mini-goal on red) do not count; restart with the other team.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Set up teams, goals, neutral and EyeQ cones as described.  
2. Start play with a coach pass or GK distribution; the receiving team attacks based on the current mission cue.  
3. On red, they attack the big goal directly with normal build-up.  
4. On red + green, they must first find the neutral target player on halfway, then attack the big goal.  
5. On blue, they must switch play and attempt to score in one of the two wide mini-goals.  
6. After each goal or ball out, the coach quickly restarts play and the EyeQ system may change the mission colour.  
7. When possession turns over during play, the new team must instantly re-scan the cones and attack according to the updated mission.

Coaching Points
- “Lift your head on the turnover” – scan cones before the first touch after winning the ball.  
- Encourage players to call out the mission (“Red big goal!”, “Red/Green target!”, “Blue mini-goals!”) so everyone shares the cue.  
- On Mission 2, emphasise quality of the pass to and from the neutral; treat them like a classic target or 10.  
- On Mission 3, stress smart switching – use width, third-man combinations or driven diagonals.  
- Focus on good body shape and first touches that keep options open towards the mission target.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Start with only Red and Blue missions; add Red+Green once players are comfortable.  
- Easier: Allow a goal in any target that broadly matches the mission (e.g. blue = any wide goal or zone).  
- Harder: Add a touch limit (e.g. 2-touch) in the middle third to speed up scanning and decisions.  
- Harder: Restrict time after turnover (e.g. must attempt to score within 8 seconds of winning the ball).  
- Harder: Give bonus points for goals scored where the team clearly reacted quickly to a new mission (e.g. within 3 passes of cue change).

title: Find Your Colour and Finish
overview: Attackers move into the final third with the ball while EyeQ SmartCones near multiple finishing zones light up in different colours. Each attacker is assigned a colour at the start; they can only shoot when their colour is active. The team must combine and manoeuvre to get the right player into a shooting position at the right moment. The exercise trains creative attacking play, selflessness and finishing under variable conditions.
description:
Drill Overview
A chaos finishing pattern with two ball colours (Red Ball, Green Ball), mixed bib colours and four EyeQ mini-goals (two red, two green). Players pass and move freely with both balls until a colour cue appears; then the correct ball, bib colour and mini-goal must all match for a valid finish, forcing players to track multiple pieces of information.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Improve players’ ability to scan for multiple cues (ball colour, bib colour, goal colour) and coordinate finishing actions quickly and accurately.  
Scanning emphasis: Players must know at all times where both balls are, which team-mates share their bib colour and where the matching mini-goals sit. When a colour cue appears, they must link that colour to the right ball, bib and goal; ignoring any part of this chain leads to invalid attempts and missed scoring opportunities.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 6–10 players  
Area: 30m x 20m rectangle (adjust to numbers).  
Players: 6–10 attackers, mixed red and green bibs, all on the same “team”.  
Equipment required: 4 mini-goals made from pairs of EyeQ SmartCones (2 red goals, 2 green goals), 2 balls (one designated Red Ball, one Green Ball), flat markers for area, red and green bibs.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Two EyeQ mini-goals on one long side (one red, one green) and two on the opposite long side; each pair displays either red or green to match its goal colour.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- When the system activates red, only the red EyeQ mini-goals are live. A valid score requires: Red Ball + red-bib finisher + red mini-goal.  
- When green is activated, only the green goals are live, using Green Ball and green-bib finisher.  
- If wrong ball, wrong bib colour or wrong goal is used, the attempt does not count and play continues.  
- If no goal is scored while that colour is active, play continues until the next colour cue.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. All players mix inside the area, some wearing red bibs and some green.  
2. Coach serves both balls into play: Red Ball and Green Ball.  
3. Players pass and move freely with whichever ball comes to them, scanning for balls, team-mates and goals.  
4. When the EyeQ system activates a colour cue (red or green), players must rapidly coordinate:
   - If red: red-bib players use Red Ball to attack either red mini-goal.  
   - If green: green-bib players use Green Ball to attack either green mini-goal.  
5. Non-target colour players help circulate the “wrong” ball and avoid confusion.  
6. After a scoring attempt or time window, colour cue resets and players go back to free passing until the next activation.  
7. Rotate bib colours and roles regularly so players experience both sides.

Coaching Points
- Emphasise scanning across the whole pitch – where are both balls, where are the goals, who shares your colour?  
- Encourage players to pre-orient their body so they can see play on both sides.  
- Demand composure in finishing – “quick mind, calm finish”.  
- Stress communication (“Red on!”, “Green ball!”, “Left red goal!”) to support scanning.  
- Highlight anticipation; players should move into good positions for their colour even before the cue appears.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Ignore bib colours initially – any player can finish as long as Red Ball goes into red goal, Green Ball into green goal.  
- Easier: Keep only one ball in play to reduce complexity.  
- Harder: Require finishes to be one-touch only when the cue appears.  
- Harder: Add 1–2 passive defenders who can block finishes but not tackles.  
- Harder: Add a time limit (e.g. 4 seconds) to score after the colour cue appears.

title: Red or Green Pass-Through
overview: A passing pattern where players navigate through a series of gates or zones, each controlled by an EyeQ SmartCone showing red or green. Players may only pass through or into a zone when the cone is green. If a player or the ball enters a red zone, possession is lost. The drill demands excellent vision, anticipation and disciplined decision-making as players weave through a constantly shifting maze.
description:
Drill Overview
Pairs pass and move inside a 20m square while eight EyeQ gates (two per side) light in red, green or blue. Each pair shares a bib colour (red or green), and the cue colour determines which pairs may attack which gates. Players must scan to choose the best gate and coordinate who runs and who passes through.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop scanning, quick role decisions between partners and accuracy of passing through small gates under time pressure.  
Scanning emphasis: While passing, both players in each pair must monitor the EyeQ gates on the sides. When a gate lights in their colour, or blue for all, they must quickly decide who dribbles and who stays to pass. Failing to scan leads to chasing dead gates or missing good opportunities.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 8–16 players (pairs)  
Area: 20m x 20m square.  
Players: Pairs of players inside the square, each pair sharing the same bib colour (red or green).  
Equipment required: 8 EyeQ SmartCones to create 4 gates (2 per side) or 16 SmartCones for 8 gates (2-per-gate), flat markers for pitch, 1 ball per pair, bibs.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: On each side of the square, set up two EyeQ gates (1–2m wide) using SmartCones. Gates can light red, green or blue.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Red light: only red-bib pairs may attack a red-lit gate.  
- Green light: only green-bib pairs may attack a green-lit gate.  
- Blue light: any pair (red or green) may attack any blue-lit gate.  
- A valid action requires a pass that goes through the lit gate to the partner on the far side. Going to an unlit or wrong-coloured gate, or failing to pass through the gate, means the attempt does not count.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. All pairs start inside the square, each with a ball, passing and moving.  
2. EyeQ gates on the sidelines light up in red, green or blue.  
3. When a pair sees a gate light in their bib colour (or blue), they decide quickly:
   - One player stays inside with the ball.  
   - The other sprints to the chosen gate.  
4. The inside player must pass the ball through the lit gate to their partner who has moved beyond it.  
5. After receiving, the outside player passes the ball back into the square and both players re-enter to continue passing.  
6. If they move to a wrong gate, pass without going through, or are too slow, they reset and find another chance.  
7. Continue for set intervals, then swap bib colours or partners.

Coaching Points
- Head up while passing – players should see both the ball and the gates.  
- Quick role decision: “Who stays, who goes?” as soon as a gate lights.  
- Accurate, firm passes through the gate to feet or into stride.  
- Timing of the runner’s movement so they arrive just as the pass is played.  
- Encourage use of both feet when passing and receiving.

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Allow the ball-carrier to dribble through the correct gate and then pass back.  
- Easier: Use fewer gates so choices are simpler.  
- Harder: Add 1–2 defenders inside the square who try to intercept passes.  
- Harder: Require a one-touch wall pass through the gate (in–out combination).  
- Harder: Set a target number of successful gate passes in a time limit for each pair.

title: Panoramic Lanes 6v6
overview: A 6v6 match across a wide pitch divided into multiple vertical lanes, each monitored by an EyeQ SmartCone. When a lane lights up in a team's colour, only that team can use that lane for a set period. Teams must recognise which lanes are available, shift players into open space and exploit the width intelligently. The exercise develops panoramic scanning, spatial rotation and dynamic use of width in possession.
description:
Drill Overview
A directional 6v6 game on a pitch divided into three vertical lanes (left, middle, right). Lane-specific EyeQ SmartCones light to show which lane is currently “live”. Before a team is allowed to score, the ball must enter the live lane at least once in that attack and be controlled there by an attacker, forcing play to relate to the full width of the pitch.

Objective & Scanning Emphasis
Objective: Develop wide-angle scanning, intelligent lane selection and patient build-up play that uses the whole pitch rather than crowding the ball.  
Scanning emphasis: On every regain, players follow a simple scan sequence: check nearest pressure and support, then immediately scan the EyeQ cones to see which lane is active, then sweep their gaze across the pitch to locate that lane and the best route into it. Failing to scan leads to goals that don’t count or missed chances to exploit space.

Setup & Equipment
Recommended Numbers: 12 players (6v6)  
Area: 40m x 30m rectangular pitch, divided lengthways into three equal vertical lanes with flat markers.  
Players: 2 teams of 6 outfield players (6v6).  
Equipment required: 2 full-size or medium goals (one at each end, or two mini-goals side-by-side), 6 EyeQ SmartCones (2 per lane, one at each end), flat markers, bibs, several balls.  
EyeQ Smart Cone placement: Place SmartCones at both ends of each lane (left, middle, right), clearly visible from all areas.

EyeQ Cue Rules (Colour / Cue Key)
- Assign each lane a fixed colour for the session (e.g. Left = Red, Middle = Green, Right = Blue).  
- At any moment, one lane’s cones light in its colour, indicating that lane is active.  
- To be eligible to score in that attack, the ball must be passed or dribbled into the active lane and controlled by an attacker inside it at least once.  
- If a team scores without using the active lane, the goal does not count and play restarts with a free-kick or pass for the opposition.

How to Play (Step-by-Step)
1. Mark out the pitch, divide into three vertical lanes and place goals and lanes’ SmartCones.  
2. Start play as a normal 6v6 game with a kick-off or coach pass.  
3. On each regain, the attacking team wins the ball, lifts heads to see which lane is currently active, then plans how to reach it.  
4. Players are free to move through any lane, but a valid attack must include a controlled action (pass or dribble) into the active lane.  
5. Once this condition is met, the team can finish from any lane.  
6. If a goal is scored without having fulfilled the active-lane condition, the goal is waved off and the opponents restart.  
7. Continue for several games, switching which lane tends to be targeted by the EyeQ pattern to vary demands.

Coaching Points
- On regain, demand an instant head lift to locate the active lane (EyeQ lights).  
- Encourage first touches and body positions that allow the ball-carrier to see across at least two lanes.  
- Wide players should stretch the pitch when their lane is active; central players look to switch quickly when a far lane is live.  
- Stress that the best route into the active lane may be via short sets, third-man runs or recycling, not just direct long passes.  
- Promote constant communication – “Red lane on!”, “Blue free!”, “Switch to Green!”

Progressions and Variations
- Easier: Use only two lanes (left and right) to start, adding the middle lane later.  
- Easier: Relax the rule so the ball only needs to travel through the active lane by pass, without requiring control inside it.  
- Harder: Limit players in the middle lane to two touches to speed up decisions.  
- Harder: Add one or two neutrals who always play with the team in possession to increase options and scanning complexity.  
- Harder: Award extra points for goals that come after a quick switch into the active far-side lane.
